The clinical ethnographic database generated by the EMIC integrates quantitative and qualitative data with respect to patterns of distress, perceived causes, help seeking and general illness beliefs. The majority of patients studied emphasized somatic complaints and were concerned about personal and family stigma. `'Nerves'' were most frequently cited as most important perceived cause. Few patients were satisfied with the allopathic help most had received previously. Questions about madness, considered distinctly different from their own problems, elicited a pattern of responses resembling their own problems. Complementary use of the EMIC and instruments like SCID and HDARS provides a method for cross-cultural research that integrates personal experience and professional concepts of illness.
keywords: EMIC; CROSS-CULTURAL PSYCHIATRY; RELIABILITY; DEPRESSION; SOMATIZATION; SCID;Pilot Projects;Anthropology, Cultural

title: THE CONTINUITY OF BEHAVIORAL EXPRESSION AMONG DISINHIBITED AND INHIBITED CHILDHOOD SUBTYPES
authors: WINDLE, M and WINDLE, RC
location: THE BOULEVARD, LANGFORD LANE, KIDLINGTON, OXFORD OX5 1GB, ENGLAND
abstract: This article focuses on issues related to the continuity and specificity/ generality of inhibitory and disinhibitory behaviors from childhood to adolescence. Literature pertinent to the stability and predictive validity of inhibitory (internalizing) and disinhibitory (externalizing) behaviors is reviewed, in addition to selected comorbid subtypes, including a `'mixed'' subtype characterized by high levels of both inhibitory and disinhibitory behaviors. Whereas empirical support for prospective relations typically has been indicated for the continuity and predictive validity of disinhibitory behaviors, this review suggests that a budding literature supports prospective relations for inhibitory behaviors and, to some extent, for the behaviors of a mixed subtype. Data from a relatively large, nonclinical adolescent sample are used to further demonstrate the proposed prospective relations among childhood inhibitory, disinhibitory, and mixed subtypes, and the expression of serious internalizing and externalizing problems in adolescence. Future research directions are proposed that emphasize prospective studies of multiple diagnostic subtypes with both treatment and nontreatment populations.

title: ATTRIBUTIONS FOR HYPERACTIVE AND AGGRESSIVE CHILD BEHAVIORS
authors: JOHNSTON, C and PATENAUDE, RL and INMAN, GA
location: 72 SPRING STREET, NEW YORK, NY 10012
abstract: Two studies test differences in adult causal attributions for hyperactive and aggressive child behaviors. In Study 1, 66 young adults rated written descriptions of aggressive and hyperactive behaviors displayed by 5- and 11-year old boys. Although the two types of behavior did not differ on ratings of causal locus or stability, aggressive child behaviors were seen as significantly more controllable than hyperactive behaviors and elicited more negative reactions, especially when they occurred in older children. Both types of behavior were rated as significantly more internal in locus and more controllable in older children than in younger children. In Study 2, 120 young adults rated descriptions that combined hyperactive and aggressive child behaviors. Hyperactive behaviors presented in the context of aggressive behaviors were rated as significantly more controllable and negative than hyperactive behaviors occurring in purely hyperactive contexts. In addition, hyperactive contexts reduced ratings of control and negativity for aggressive behaviors. Implications for understanding how adults interpret and react to aggressive and hyperactive behaviors in children are discussed.
keywords: Only Child;Child;Child Behavior;Aggression

title: ATTRIBUTIONS OF MENTAL-ILLNESS AND JUDGMENTS ABOUT HELP SEEKING AMONG JAPANESE-AMERICAN AND WHITE AMERICAN STUDENTS
authors: NARIKIYO, TA and KAMEOKA, VA
location: 750 FIRST ST NE, WASHINGTON, DC 20002-4242
abstract: Perceived causes of mental illness and help-seeking preferences among Japanese-American and White American college students (72 men and 72 women in each ethnic group) were compared in order to investigate the reported underuse of mental health services by Japanese Americans. Results of a 2 (ethnicity of subject) x 2 (severity of disorder) x 2 (gender of person with disorder) x 2 (gender of subject) multivariate analysis of variance revealed that Japanese-American students were more likely than White American students to attribute mental illness to social causes, to resolve problems on their own, and to seek help from family members or friends or both. Possible barriers to use of services by this sample of Japanese Americans include both a preference for informal resources and the stigmatization of mental illness.
keywords: Asian Americans;European Continental Ancestry Group

title: EXPERTISE AND CAUSAL ATTRIBUTION IN DECIDING BETWEEN CRIME AND MENTAL DISORDER
authors: SMITH, R
location: 6 BONHILL STREET, LONDON, ENGLAND EC2A 4PU
keywords: Crime;Mental Disorders;Causality

title: Attribution theory concepts and outpatients' perceptions of the causal locus of their psychological problems
authors: Calhoun, Lawrence G. and Peirce, J. R. and Dawes, A. Stephen
abstract: Administered a questionnaire to 53 male and 64 female outpatients at a mental health clinic. The correlation between perceived locus of causal attribution for psychological problems and 3 possible correlates derived from attribution theory (typicalness, duration, and severity of the psychological problem) was examined. Results indicate that problems perceived as caused by internal factors tended to be seen as more severe and as having lasted a longer period of time. Results with typicalness were inconclusive. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: attribution theory;perceptions of causal locus of psychological problems;mental health clinic outpatients;Attribution;Internal External Locus of Control;Outpatients;Psychiatric Clinics;Causality

title: Determinants of social rejection for help seeking: Locus of causal attribution, help source, and the 'mental illness' label
journal: Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology
authors: Calhoun, Lawrence G. and Peirce, J. R. and Walters, Stephen and Dawes, A. Stephen
abstract: 150 19-64 yr old men read a booklet containing a description of an adult male currently seeking help from a friend, a mental health center, or a clinical psychologist and a paragraph in which the helper attributed the seeker's problem to either internal or external factors. The type of help-source did not reliably affect the Ss' social rejection ratings or the degree of rated mental illness; however, there was a significant positive correlation between social rejection and ratings of mental illness. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: causal attribution & help source & degree of rated mental illness;social rejection of help-seeker;19-64 yr olds;Adult;Attitude;Humans;Male;Mental Disorders;Middle Aged;Social Perception;Mental Illness (Attitudes Toward);Social Acceptance;Social Values

title: Social perception of suicide: Effects of three factors on causal attributions
journal: Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology
authors: Selby, James W. and Calhoun, Lawrence G.
abstract: Experimental results show that, among 76 female and 83 male undergraduates, the sex of the individual described as having engaged in suicidal behavior tended to produce a significant difference in the degree of inferred intentionality, with suicidal females being seen as having greater suicidal intentionality than males. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: sex of S & person described as committing vs attempting suicide;attribution of intentionality;male vs female college students;Female;Humans;Male;Mental Disorders;Personality;Sex Factors;Social Perception;Stress;Psychological;Suicide;Attempted;Attempted Suicide;Attribution;Human Sex Differences;Causality

authors: Johnson, Richard E. and Calhoun, Lawrence G. and Boardman, William K.
abstract: The article focuses on the effect of severity, consistency and typical information on clinicians' causal attributions. Attribution theory, which deals with the antecedents and consequences of judgments about the causes of behavior, has inspired a number of recent studies. Clinical inferences by mental health professionals as to the causal variables related to a client's problem generally are viewed as systematic, but little research has been done to determine the variables that affect the types of causal inferences that clinicians tend to make about a client's condition. A variety of informational factors may influence the causal attributions that are drawn to account for an individual's behavior, and data and theory have suggested a number of variables for nonclinical situations.
keywords: MENTAL health personnel & patient;MENTAL health;CLINICAL psychologists;REASONING;PATHOLOGICAL psychology;CLINICAL psychology

title: Causal attributions for success and failure for psychiatric rehabilitees and college students
journal: Journal of Personality and Social Psychology
authors: Menapace, Robert H. and Doby, Carol
abstract: 40 college students and 40 psychiatric rehabilitees performed a manual dexterity task in which consistent success or failure was manipulated over 4 consecutive task trials. Contrasting predictions for the use of causal attributions (luck, task difficulty, effort, and ability) following Trial 1 and Trial 4 for the 2 populations were derived from R. Heider's (1958) balance theory and 'naive theory of action.' Consistent with naive theory, students who succeeded and rehabilitees who failed used stable attributions to account for these first trial outcomes, whereas students who failed and rehabilitees who succeeded used unstable attributions. Only college students who failed made significant changes in their attributional patterns from Trial 1 to Trial 4. Results are discussed regarding intervention with psychiatric rehabilitees and other groups with severe achievement difficulties. (23 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: consistent failure vs success over trials on manual dexterity task;stability of attributions of outcome on 1st trial & changes in attribution patterns over trials;college students vs psychiatric rehabilitees;Achievement;Adult;Attitude;Female;Humans;Male;Mental Disorders;Methods;Students;Universities;Attribution;Expectations;Failure;Psychiatric Patients

title: Perceived causes of psychological problems: An exploratory study
authors: Selby, James W. and Calhoun, Lawrence G. and Johnson, Richard E.
abstract: Explored the major categories of causal explanations used by naive observers to account for psychological problems. A pool of items describing potential causes of psychological problems was generated using psychiatric and psychological theory and research and pilot work. 394 undergraduates rated each cause. Results were factor analyzed, and 5 interpretable factors resulted: Factor I, Personal Characteristics; Factor II, Organic Causes; Factor III, Natural Disasters; Factor IV, Marital Crises; and Factor V, Childhood Family Conditions. It is suggested that these 5 dimensions can be useful in further study of the perceived causes of psychological disorders. (15 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: causal explanation of psychological problems;college students;Attribution;Mental Illness (Attitudes Toward)

title: Effects of prior diagnostic information on clinicians' causal attributions of a client's problems
journal: Journal of Consulting and Clinical Psychology
authors: Shenkel, R and ee J. and Snyder, C. R. and Batson, C. Daniel and Clark, Gary M.
abstract: 63 female social welfare students listened to a taped therapy interview, and the degree to which they attributed the client's problems to personality vs situational factors was explored. Results support the hypothesis that previous tentative diagnoses result in personality-based attributions. A recency effect suggested that personality attributions may be lessened by presenting situational information after hearing the client. (3 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: prior diagnostic knowledge;causal attributions of client's problems;female social welfare students;Attitude of Health Personnel;Female;Humans;Mental Disorders;Personality;Social Environment;Attribution;Counselor Attitudes;Counselor Trainees;Knowledge Level;Psychodiagnosis;Causality

title: Attribution of mental disorders: A preliminary report
authors: Hatcher, April S. and Schultz, E. Eugene
abstract: Typically, individuals assign blame to victims of unfortunate circumstances. When external constraints are increased, less blame is usually assigned. In the present study, causal attribution for mental disorders was examined in 96 undergraduates by varying external constraints. Results yielded no consistent external or internal attributions; this suggests an important exception to the tendency to blame victims. (4 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: variations in external constraints;causal attributions of mental disorders;college students;Attribution;Mental Disorders;Responsibility

title: The sociogenesis of psychological disorder: An attributional theory
journal: Journal of Health and Social Behavior
authors: Wheaton, Blair
abstract: Before social causation explanations of psychological disorder can be considered plausible, the process by which social factors may affect the development of disorder must be made explicit in terms of a given theory. The present paper formulates an attributional theory intended primarily to explain social status effects, although other applications are possible. The point of departure for this model is the socializing influence of socioeconomic status on causal attribution tendencies (i.e., fatalism) and the resulting variation in vulnerability to psychological disorder. Data from 2 panel studies (1,322 Ss) suggest that causal attribution styles could in fact play a central role in the mediation of social causation of disorder. Comparisons of 2 contrasting versions of the attributional model show that a simple, linear interpretation of the intervening effects of fatalism may be the most adequate. (53 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: causal attribution model;sociogenesis of psychological disorder;Adaptation;Psychological;Adolescent;Attitude;Humans;Internal-External Control;Male;Mental Disorders;Models;Personality Disorders;Social Behavior;Social Environment;Socioeconomic Factors;Stress;Attribution;Etiology;Socioeconomic Status;Fatalism

title: Blaminga sign of psychosocial tensions in the community: Findings from two surveys
authors: Zautra, Alex and Young, David M. and Guenther, Robert T.
abstract: An 8-item blame scale was constructed to tap the areas about which an S made causal attributions to explain misfortune. This scale, along with the Social Readjustment Rating Scale and other measures, was administered through household surveys to 2 samples of 537 and 185 community residents. Consistent with the predictions of the study, demographic groups with fewer social resources had higher blame scores, and residents reporting more stressful life events were more likely to blame. Blame attributions were positively correlated with maladjustment and were unrelated to a separate measure of positive well-being. Discontent with social life, followed by financial situation, family life, and life opportunity blame, were consistently related to reports of maladjustment. Self-blame, however, was only marginally associated with poor adjustment. (30 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: maladjustment & few social resources & stressful life events;attributions for discontent with social life & financial situation & family life & life opportunity;community residents;Adult;Aged;Displacement (Psychology);Female;Humans;Life Change Events;Male;Mental Disorders;Middle Aged;Personal Satisfaction;Scapegoating;Social Environment;Attribution;Community Attitudes;Dissatisfaction;Emotional Adjustment;Stress;Life Experiences

title: Attributional biases among clinicians and nonclinicians
authors: Harari, Oren and Hosey, Karen R.
abstract: Presented 27 randomly chosen clinicians and 18 nonclinicians with a series of statements that described deviant and nondeviant actor behavior and employed the social psychological constructs of emotion, action, and opinion. Ss made a series of causal attributions of actor behaviors. Data were subjected to both univariate ANOVA and MANOVA. Data show a clear dispositional attribution bias among both clinicians and nonclinicians across all stimulus statements. Further specific tests revealed that clinicians did not differ from each other or from nonclinicians in their attributions and that a significantly greater dispositional bias occurred with deviant actor behavior and in situations that featured actor actions over opinions over emotions. (21 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: biases in causal attributions of actor's deviant vs nondeviant behavior;psychiatrists & psychologists & social workers vs psychology graduate students & college students;Attitude of Health Personnel;Humans;Mental Disorders;Mental Health Services;Attribution;Psychiatrists;Psychologists;Response Bias;Social Workers;College Students;Graduate Students;Bias (Epidemiology)

title: Clinicians' judgments of female clients' causal attributions
authors: Compas, Bruce E. and Adelman, Howard S.
abstract: 400 clinical psychologists were presented with statements of female client attributions for presenting problems for which locus of causality varied. Ss' judgments of clients were investigated through their evaluations of the accuracy of these attributions. While Ss did not differ in estimate of accuracy based on whether attribution were internal or external, female Ss were more likely than males to judge client attributions as accurate. (10 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: female clients' locus of causal attribution & sex of clinician;judgment of attribution accuracy;clinical psychologists;Adult;Aged;Attitude of Health Personnel;Female;Gender Identity;Humans;Identification (Psychology);Internal-External Control;Male;Mental Disorders;Middle Aged;Personality;Psychology;Clinical;Social Adjustment;Attribution;Client Characteristics;Clinical Psychologists;Human Females;Human Sex Differences;Psychodiagnosis;Therapist Attitudes;Causality

title: Learned helplessness: From concept to comprehension
authors: Murphy, Shirley A.
abstract: Reviews the development of learned helplessness theory and its clinical applications in the area of psychiatric/mental health nursing. It is noted that causal attributions are classified along 3 dimensions: personal/universal, stable/unstable, and global/specific. Transitional events are discussed in terms of the aging and chronically ill, and situational events are examined in terms of multiple negative stressors and sudden disability. Intervention strategies are outlined. (22 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
notes: RAYYAN-INCLUSION: {"Isaac"=>"Excluded", "Fiona"=>"Excluded", "Consensus"=>"Excluded"} | RAYYAN-EXCLUSION-REASONS: not sure if learned helplessness counts
keywords: development of theory of learned helplessness & clinical applications in psychiatric/mental health nursing;literature review;Adult;Aged;Attitude;Behavior;Depression;Female;Humans;Internal-External Control;Life Change Events;Male;Middle Aged;Models;Psychological;Psychiatric Nursing;Learned Helplessness;Literature Review;Nursing;Psychiatric Nurses;Theories;Helplessness, Learned

title: Kontrollerwartung, Ursachenattribution und psychische Strungen: Die Bedeutung des Konstrukts 'locus of control' fr die klinische Psychologie = Locus of control, causal attribution and psychic disorders: The usefulness of the 'locus of control' construct for clinical psychology
authors: Br and , Johannes
abstract: A comparison of the models of learned helplessness (LH) and stress with the concept of locus of control (LOC) extended by attributional considerations shows a principal correspondence of the 3 models. Their integration in a general theory of behavior is proposed. LH, stress, and LOC are specifications of this general theory, and each describe specific emotional-behavioral states. The usefulness of the concept of LOC for a differential description of mental disorders is demonstrated in clinical cases of schizophrenia, depression, alcoholism, and psychosomatic disorders. The necessity of including individual patterns of LOC in the assessment and therapy of mental disorders is discussed. (80 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: locus of control & attribution & learned helplessness & stress models;mental disorders;literature review;Attribution;Internal External Locus of Control;Learned Helplessness;Mental Disorders;Stress;Literature Review;Models;Internal-External Control;Self Psychology;Psychology

title: Locus of control, repressionsensitization, and interpersonal causality
authors: Spring, Richard and Khanna, Prabha
abstract: Investigated the relationship between repressionsensitization and multidimensional locus of control, particularly as these variables relate to a 3rd variable, the attribution of causality in interpersonal relationships. 41 1762 yr old male psychiatric inpatients were employed as Ss, of whom 18 were from an acute general inpatient unit and 23 from an alcohol and drug unit. Eight independent variables were considered. There were 8 dependent variables that were derived from an attribution measure. Stepwise multiple regression analyses indicated that the variable having the most predictive power with respect to causal attributions was the subsample represented by the S. A 2nd analysis, excluding subsample considerations, showed that the Powerful Others scale was positively correlated with Internal-Positive attributions. (43 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: locus of control & repression-sensitization;attribution of causality in interpersonal relationships;1762 yr old male psychiatric inpatients;Adolescent;Adult;Humans;Internal-External Control;Interpersonal Relations;Male;Mental Disorders;Middle Aged;Repression-Sensitization;Attribution;Internal External Locus of Control;Interpersonal Interaction;Psychiatric Patients;Repression Sensitization;Causality

title: Goal conflicts in correctional institutions for juvenile delinquents
authors: Klingemann, Harald K.
abstract: Investigated goal conflicts in 5 open, closed, mixed, and public education correctional institutions for juvenile delinquents and predelinquents. 322 staff members completed the Correctional Practices Questionnaire and indicated the actual percentage of daily work performed for administration, custody, and treatment. Attitudinal data on correctional goals and the perceived causes of crime indicated that the majority of Ss agreed with educational training and therapy aiming at legal conformity or personal maturity and autonomy. The majority of Ss also agreed that remorse and deterrence were correctional goals; 53% held the opinion that habitual offenders are born criminals; a rather restrictive attitude toward inmates was typical for the issue of the ideal degree of inmate participation in different areas. A significant reduction of custodial activities was advocated when Ss' actual time budget was compared with what they considered the ideal time budget. Results indicate that atonement, guilt, custody, and deterrence were connected with the appreciation of work conformity as a means of rehabilitation. Overall findings do not support the hypothesis of the functional necessity of goal conflicts. (41 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: goal conflicts in correctional institutions for juvenile delinquents;institutional staff members;Correctional Institutions;Goals;Juvenile Delinquency;Mental Health Personnel

title: Causal attributions to emotional disturbance and/or supernatural influence: Effects of sex, locus of control, and prior personality traits
authors: Hedgespeth, Joanne
keywords: sex & locus of control & prior personality traits of actor;causal attributions about disturbed emotional behavior &/or supernatural influences;male vs female Christian college students;Attribution;Human Sex Differences;Mental Illness (Attitudes Toward);Personality Traits;Sex Role Attitudes;Christianity;Internal External Locus of Control;Religious Beliefs;Stereotyped Attitudes;Affective Symptoms;Internal-External Control

title: Individuals as agents of change: Pro person-centered interventions from a community perspective
authors: Smead, Valerie S.
abstract: A review of community psychology and community mental health literatures provides ample evidence that while professionals conceptualize on a global systems level, they do not usually intervene beyond the individual/small group level (L. McClure et al, 1980). The present article attempts to tie together one of the major conceptual frameworks of community psychologyan ecological perspective on behaviorto practical interventions that may be applied to the real world of the community mental health center. Specifically, the following issues are discussed: the critical issues relating theory and practice in utilizing the ecological perspective, the characteristics of the person and the environment, the avoidance of person- and environment-centered causal attribution biases, ecologically based interventions for individuals, and micro-level interventions to aid the individual in distress. (26 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: ecological perspective in treatment planning;community mental health centers;Community Mental Health Centers;Treatment

title: Variations in problem conceptualizations and intended solutions among Hong Kong students
journal: Culture, Medicine, and Psychiatry: An International Journal of Cross-Cultural Health Research
authors: Cheung, Fanny M. and Lee, Sik-yum and Chan, Yuk Yee
abstract: Used a cognitive schema to explain health and illness behaviors among 78 1926 yr old Chinese university students in Hong Kong. Ss were asked to attribute causes and suggest solutions to 5 health/mental health problems: weakness/fatigue, tension/anxiety, sleep difficulty, hollow/emptiness, and headache. The patterns of endorsement on the causal and solution categories used for the 5 problems were compared using a new asymptotic chi-squared test. The response patterns were found to be significantly different across the 5 problems. Each problem was attributed to multiple causes, including psychological, social, situational, somatic, and existential factors. The intended solutions were often related to the nature of the causal attributions especially when the problems were mild. In lay help-seeking, Ss would attempt a variety of self-help measures. However, for professional consultation, the medical doctor would be the primary care professional the Ss would turn to for most of the problems except in the case of hollow/emptiness. (31 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2019 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: conceptualization of cause of & solutions to health & illness behaviors;1926 yr old college students;Hong Kong;Adult;Anxiety;Attitude to Health;Concept Formation;Ethnic Groups;Fatigue;Female;Headache;Humans;Male;Problem Solving;Psychophysiologic Disorders;Referral and Consultation;Sleep Initiation and Maintenance Disorders;Attribution;Health Behavior;Illness Behavior;Student Attitudes;College Students

title: Causal attributions to emotional disturbance and/or supernatural phenomena as seen in the Chinese-American subculture
authors: Boykin, Eunice
keywords: cultural identity & causal attributions for emotional disturbance or supernatural phenomena;Chinese American adults;Asians;Attribution;Ethnic Identity;Mental Disorders;Parapsychological Phenomena;Cultural Identity;Affective Symptoms;Asian Americans

title: Un modelo terico de los procesos psicolgicos de las personas afectadas de paro laboral = A model of psychological processes of unemployed people
journal: Psiquis: Revista de Psiquiatra, Psicologa y Psicosomtica
authors: Ortiz Zbala, Milagros
abstract: Proposes an unemployment psychopathology model, based on an assumption of its damaging effects to health and on the learned helplessness theory proposed by Seligman (1975). The model analyzes the causal attributions and locus of control of the situation as it is perceived by the unemployed and applies various therapeutic strategies designed to prevent and cure the possible psychopathological effects of unemployment. (English abstract) (14 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: model of psychopathological effects of unemployment;Psychopathology;Unemployment;Psychodynamics;Treatment;Models, Psychological

title: Families of the mentally ill in cross-cultural perspective
authors: Lefley, Harriet P.
abstract: Presents an analytic review of the cross-cultural literature on families of the seriously mentally ill. It is argued that Western values, ideological theories, and correlative treatment approaches may adversely affect client progress. Differential attitudes toward families, causal attribution, dependency issues, and expectancy levels in individualized and traditional cultures are discussed. The advantages of supportive networks for both clients and families are seen as related to emergent roles of family advocacy organizations. Issues related to the International Pilot Studies of Schizophrenia, the expressed emotion studies conducted by the British Medical Research Council's Social Psychiatry Unit, treatment perspectives, and deinstitutionalization are examined. The review indicates that societies believing in an external locus of control for mental illness subscribe to a disease model, view the afflicted individual as sick rather than as an agent of his or her own disability, apply realistic expectancy levels to functioning and productivity of the patient, and show more benign family relationships and lower rates of hospitalization. Societies that stress mutual interdependence rather than independent functioning provide a more salutary climate for the severely disabled. Implications for the psychosocial approach to rehabilitation are discussed. (3 p ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: cross cultural perspectives;families of seriously mentally ill;literature review;implications for psychosocial rehabilitation;Cross Cultural Differences;Literature Review;Mental Illness (Attitudes Toward);Psychosocial Rehabilitation;Social Support;Family;Mental Disorders;Mentally Ill Persons

title: Depressive irrationality
authors: Cook, Michele L. and Peterson, Christopher
abstract: In accordance with A. T. Beck's (1967) cognitive theory of depression, irrational thinking by depressives was assessed among 11 female undergraduates who met Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders (DSM-III) criteria for depression and 11 nondepressed female undergraduates. Ss completed the Beck Depression Inventory and the Irrational Beliefs Test and were then asked to describe 3 bad events they had experienced during the last year. Depressed Ss endorsed self-deprecating statements and used illogical justification for causal beliefs to a greater degree than nondepressed Ss, supporting the hypothesis that depressives are irrational in their beliefs and in the ways beliefs are justified. Limitations on the generalizability of these results are discussed, such as the fact that only 1 S was in treatment. (16 ref) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: irrational beliefs;depressed vs nondepressed college students;Depression (Emotion);Irrational Beliefs;Depression

title: A longitudinal analysis of the effects of different patterns of employment and unemployment on school-leavers
authors: Feather, N. T. and O'Brien, G. E.
abstract: 3,456 young employed and unemployed respondents (in Years 10, 11, and 12 of high school) in Adelaide, South Australia, completed questionnaires on 2 occasions 1 yr apart. There was little evidence from analyses of change scores that a shift from employment to unemployment or the reverse transition had significant effects on psychological well-being, but unemployment attributions were affected. The shift from employment to unemployment led to less internal and more external causal attributions for youth unemployment; the reverse transition had the opposite effects. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: patterns of employment & unemployment;psychological well being & unemployment attributions;10th12th grade school leavers;Australia;1 yr longitudinal study;Attribution;Employment Status;Mental Health;School Leavers;Unemployment;Longitudinal Studies;Employment

title: Causal attributions for psychological illness among Turkish psychiatric in-patients and their relationships with hope
authors: Karanci, Nuray A.
abstract: Studied 12 female and 58 male in-patients (aged 1567 yrs) in psychiatric departments of 3 hospitals in Ankara, Turkey, for their causal attributions of the development of their illness, the impact of culture on these statements, and their predictive power for illness and hope for future well-being. Ss completed a 2-part questionnaire based on J. Prochaska's (1984) transtheoretical model. The Statistical Package for the Social Sciences Varimax rotated orthogonal analysis subprogram showed 7 causal content areas: interpersonal conflicts, family conflicts, conflicts with the family of origin, fate and material problems, personal traits blamed on others, lack of will power, and personal symptoms. Factors include self-familial domain, externalized blame, and uncontrollable domain. Five variables predicted hope for future well-being. Non-Western familial and cultural traits and attributions must be considered when working in Turkey. (French abstract) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: illness attribution & prediction & cultural impact & hope for well being;1567 yr old psychiatric inpatients;Turkey;implications for research methodology in non-Western cultures;Adolescent;Adult;Aged;Alcoholism;Antisocial Personality Disorder;Anxiety Disorders;Attitude to Health;Cultural Characteristics;Culture;Depressive Disorder;Female;Humans;Male;Mental Disorders;Middle Aged;Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder;Psychological Tests;Psychophysiologic Disorders;Attribution;Health Attitudes;Prediction;Psychiatric Patients;Sociocultural Factors;Methodology

title: An analysis of ordinary explanations in clinical attribution research
journal: Journal of Social and Clinical Psychology
authors: Brewin, Chris R. and Antaki, Charles
abstract: Describes ordinary explanations as having a number of separate functions, including labeling or description, moral evaluation, causal attribution, and self-presentation. Research on attributions for physical and mental disorders is analyzed using this framework, and the relevance of each aspect of explanation to clinical psychology is outlined. It is argued that the failure to observe these distinctions has led to an unnecessarily narrow view of attribution research and therapy. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: aspects of ordinary explanations;research on attributions for physical & mental disorders;Attribution;Disorders;Mental Disorders

title: Attributions as moderator variables within social interactional systems
journal: Journal of Social and Clinical Psychology
authors: Bugental, Daphne B.
abstract: A model of social interactional systems in which causal attributions act in a moderator role is applied to malfunctioning family systems. Adult beliefs about the causes of caregiving outcomes are predicted to moderate the potential challenge or stress produced by difficult children. Caregiver affective and behavioral reactions then influence the affective and behavioral responses of the child, maintaining a continuous-loop transactional system. Evidence is cited from research on parents at risk for abuse that supports this prediction. Low perceived control over caregiving outcomes sensitized caregivers to negative child behaviors. Causal beliefs moderated the expressive reactions of both mothers and strangers to children characterized as relatively difficult or easy. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: attributions as moderator variables;social interactional system of malfunctioning family;Attribution;Family Relations;Psychopathology;Systems;Interpersonal Relations

title: Accessibility of diagnostic categories and causal attributions for an interviewee's behaviour
authors: Love, Anthony W. and Jackson, Henry J.
abstract: Investigated the effects of diagnostic category accessibility on causal attributions for an interviewee's behavior made by 65 mental health students and 36 undergraduate psychology students. In order to activate a specific diagnostic category, mental health students completed a test in which half answered questions about victims of rape attacks and half answered questions about the diagnosis of histrionic personality disorder. All Ss then rated their attribution for a female interviewee's nonverbal behavior along 4 dimensions: internality, stability, globality, and controllability. Undergraduates in the rape victim condition tended to make more stable and global attributions than did mental health students. Also, Ss in the personality disorder condition rated the cause of the interviewee's behavior as significantly more controllable than did Ss in the rape victim condition. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: focus on histrionic personality disorder vs rape;causal attributions of internality & stability & globality & controllability for interviewee nonverbal behavior;mental health & psychology students;Attribution;Clinical Judgment (Not Diagnosis);Labeling;Psychopathology;Emotional Stability;Histrionic Personality Disorder;Nonverbal Communication;Rape;Causality

title: Youth suicide in California: A comparative study of perceived causes and interventions
authors: Nelson, Franklyn L. and Farberow, Norman L. and Litman, Robert E.
abstract: Surveyed 5 sample groups of respondents composed of 1,644 young people (aged 1220 yrs), 465 parents of young people within this age range, and 44 respondents to psychological autopsies of deceased youth. Findings reveal that family dysfunction, intrapersonal psychopathology and distress, problems with interpersonal relationships, and drug and alcohol abuse were most frequently mentioned by Ss as the major causes of youth suicide. In terms of solutions, the availability of social support from family and friends and access to formal intervention programs for troubled adolescents were seen as the most effective prevention measures. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: causes of & interventions for youth suicide;1220 yr olds & parents;Achievement;Adolescent;California;Cross-Sectional Studies;Family;Female;Humans;Male;Risk Factors;Social Adjustment;Suicide;Suicide Prevention;Youth Suicide;Parents

title: Limited mental capacities and perceived control in attribution of responsibility
authors: Fincham, Frank D. and Emery, Robert E.
abstract: Examined the impact of a child's psychological disturbance on adults' judgments of causation, blame, and punishment for action outcomes portrayed across F. Heider's (1958) levels, using 197 undergraduates. The effect of these levels on perceived control and the utility of perceived control in predicting judgments were also investigated. It was found that (a) the psychological status of the child affected responses for a subset of Heider's levels but did not alter the pattern of responses across levels and (b) responses were not affected by the existence of a psychological disorder but appeared to reflect inferences regarding the capacities influenced by the disorder. Perceived control increased across Heider's levels and was more useful than previously investigated subjective probabilities in accounting for variance in perceived cause, blame, and punishment. Suggestions regarding the assessment of capacities necessary for being held accountable for one's actions are outlined. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: psychological status of child;judgments of causation & blame & punishment;college students;Attribution;Mental Disorders;Mental Illness (Attitudes Toward);Punishment;Responsibility;Perceived Control

title: Burnout and depression: A construct validity study using causal attributions
authors: Reitz, Robert M.
keywords: causal attributions;burnout & depression;mental health personnel;Attribution;Construct Validity;Depression (Emotion);Mental Health Personnel;Occupational Stress;Causality

title: Adverse effects of psychotherapeutic beliefs: An application of attribution theory to the critical study of psychotherapy
authors: Furman, Ben and Ahola, Tapani
abstract: Explores adverse effects of common psychological attributions through the frame of reference of attribution theory, which offers a way of approaching the various explanations or causal attributions that are characteristic of the various psychotherapeutic theories while maintaining a neutral position. Focus is on patients, family members, and clinicians in the discussion of the potential detrimental effects of some causal attributions, including psychopathology, family pathology, behavior of a significant other, childhood trauma, and recent psychosocial stressors. Adverse effects of psychotherapeutic beliefs on the population at large are also discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: adverse effects of common psychological attributions & attribution theory & psychotherapeutic theories;patients & family members & clinicians;Attribution;Psychotherapy;Theoretical Orientation;Clinicians;Family Members

title: Causal attributions and parent-child relationships in a self-help group for families of the mentally ill
authors: Medvene, Louis J. and Krauss, David H.
abstract: Developed a questionnaire that included sections on parents' thoughts and feelings regarding the causes of their offspring's psychiatric problems and their relationships with their disabled offspring. 57 participants in a chapter of a national self-help organization for families with at least 1 mentally ill member completed the questionnaire; most were aged 50+ yrs, and most of their disabled family members were young adults (aged 2135 yrs). Parents thought about the causes of their children's psychiatric disabilities in terms of psychogenic, moral, and organic attributions; and participation in the chapter was associated with stronger endorsement of the organic attribution, weaker endorsement of the psychogenic attribution, and the increased comfort of parents in their relationships with their disabled adult children. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
notes: RAYYAN-INCLUSION: {"Isaac"=>"Included", "Fiona"=>"Excluded", "Consensus"=>"Included"} | RAYYAN-EXCLUSION-REASONS: not sure if psychiatric disabilities count as mental health illness
keywords: parent child relations & beliefs about cause of offspring's psychiatric problems;parents & their disabled 2135 yr olds in self help organization;Attribution;Mental Disorders;Parent Child Relations;Parental Attitudes;Adult Offspring;Parents;Parent-Child Relations;Self-Help Groups

title: Depressive cognition: Models, mechanisms, and methods - Contemporary psychological approaches to depression:  Theory, research, and treatment.
authors: Ingram, Rick E. and Ingram, Rick E.
abstract: provide a broad overview of contemporary cognitive theory and research in depression  emphasize theory and data that are particularly relevant to several of the central issues in the data / specifically, our intent is to examine the major theoretical models, constructs, and important issues that currently characterize research on cognition in depression  cognitive theoretical approaches [behavioral-cognitive models, social-cognitive models, information processing models] / a meta-construct model of psychopathology [elements of the cognitive taxonomy, elements of the component model of psychopathology] / the meta-construct model applied to the cognitive mechanisms of depression [structural/propositional, propositions: dysfunctional attitudes, operations: encoding and retrieval processes, attention and activation; products: attributions and automatic thoughts] / relationships between cognitive structural, propositional, operational, and product aspects of depression / cognitive causal versus vulnerability factors [dysfunctional attitudes/vulnerability schemata, causal attributions, attentional processes] / cognitive specificity (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

authors: van Vuuren, Catharina V. and Kl and ermans, Pieter G. and Drenth, Pieter J. D. and Sergeant, Joseph A. and Takens, Roelf J.

title: Causal attributions, life events, and perceived social support of wives of alcoholic men
authors: McKenzie, Becky J.
keywords: stressful life events & perceptions of social support & causal attributions;psychiatric symptomatology;wives of alcoholic males;Alcoholism;Attribution;Life Experiences;Psychopathology;Social Support;Wives;Alcoholics

title: Appraisal and adaptation among women with impaired fertility
authors: Mendola, Richard and Tennen, Howard and Affleck, Glenn and McCann, Lisa and Fitzgerald, Terrance
abstract: Examined the independent contributions to well-being of 3 aspects of cognitive adaptation (perceived personal control, cognitive accommodations, and causal attributions) among 65 women with impaired fertility. Appraisals of personal control were not associated with psychological symptomatology. However, believing that the impaired fertility had strengthened one's marriage and attributing the experience to biomedical causes each made an independent contribution to psychological symptoms, thus supporting the conceptual distinctions among primary control, secondary cognitive accommodations, and causal attributions. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Concepts of causality applied in the clinic: Interactional models and attributional style
authors: Munton, Anthony G. and Stratton, Peter M.
abstract: Compared causal attributions made by 10 families with a variety of presenting problems, including anorexia nervosa and depression, who attended a therapy clinic with those made by 10 control families. Attributional statements were extracted from transcripts of 10 therapy sessions and 10 control interviews. Families in therapy attributed more often to global and stable causes and perceived causes as more personal and internal. Treatment implications are outlined. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: attributions & interactions;families in therapy for various presenting problems;Attribution;Family Relations;Family Therapy;Psychopathology;Causality

title: Cognition and coping in agoraphobia and depression: A multivariate approach
authors: Hoffart, Asle and Martinsen, Egil W.
abstract: Assessed 117 inpatients with anxiety and/or unipolar depressive disorders on agoraphobic and depressive symptom subscales. Factor analyses of the scales yielded an agoraphobic and a depressive factor. Ss also completed the Multidimensional Health Locus of Control Scale, the Attributional Style Questionnaire, and the Ways of Coping Check List. Stepwise regression analyses were performed with the cognitive and coping variables as independent variables. The externalizing of mental health locus of control to chance was the only significant predictor of agoraphobia factor score. Causal attributions were unrelated to agoraphobic anxiety but were consistent predictors of depression factor score. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2020 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Causal attributions and psychiatric symptoms in survivors of the Herald of Free Enterprise disaster
authors: Joseph, Steve A. and Brewin, Chris R. and Yule, William and Williams, Ruth M.
abstract: Explored the relationship between causal attributions and psychiatric symptoms in those who survived the capsizing of the Herald of Free Enterprise ferry, 2 yrs following the disaster. Symptom measures and statements were available for up to 45 1954 yr old survivors referred for psychiatric assessment at the time of the disaster. Data from 10 men and 10 women were available at 2nd assessment. Internal and controllable attributions for disaster-related experience were strongly related to poorer psychological outcome. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2018 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: causal attributions & psychiatric symptoms;1945 yr old survivors of Herald of Free Enterprise ferry capsizing;Accidents;Adult;Depression;England;Female;Follow-Up Studies;Humans;Internal-External Control;Male;Middle Aged;Personality Assessment;Psychometrics;Ships;Stress Disorders;Post-Traumatic;Survival;Attribution;Mental Disorders;Transportation Accidents;Disasters;Survivors

title: Indigenous models of helping in nonwestern countries: Implications for multicultural counseling
journal: Journal of Multicultural Counseling and Development
authors: Lee, Courtl and C. and Oh, Maria Y. and Mountcastle, Anne R.
abstract: Developed a questionnaire to discern the status of psychology and related mental health fields in non-Western countries. The questionnaire solicited responses in the following areas: perceived causes of psychological distress and behavioral deviance in a particular country, specific methods and procedures used in psychological treatment, and types of problems for which psychological treatment is most often sought. Mental health and related professionals in Barbados, Korea, Nigeria, Pakistan, Singapore, Sudan, and Zambia completed the questionnaire. There are 2 particularly important dynamics that may need to be considered in US counselors' interactions with clients from non-Western cultural backgrounds: kinship influences and religious-spiritual influences. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: perceived causes of mental distress & deviant behavior & treatment methods;mental health professionals;non-Western countries;implications for multicultural counseling;Antisocial Behavior;Counseling;Cross Cultural Differences;Mental Health Personnel;Psychological Stress;Attitudes;Poverty

title: A survey on mental health level of 1,088 middle school students
authors: Liang, Wei and Zhao, Jingping and Zheng, Yanping
abstract: Studied the mental health of secondary school students and perceived causes of psychological distress. Human Ss: 1,088 male and female Chinese school-age children and adolescents (aged 1119 yrs) (middle school and high school students in Changsha). Ss included 580 males and 508 females. The impacts of 52 life events on Ss were examined using the SCL-90. 20 life events on the SCL-90 were closely related to psychological distress; and they concerned academic study, personal or family relationships, love affairs, illnesses, and accidents. Results are discussed in terms of the incidence of obsessivecompulsive personality disorders, interpersonal sensitivity, depression, and paranoid ideation in Ss. Implications of the study are discussed concerning the need for psychological counseling and social training. (English abstract) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: academic & other life events;psychological distress & need for psychological counseling & social training;1119 yr old secondary school students;China;Distress;Experiences (Events);High School Students;Junior High School Students;Psychotherapeutic Counseling;Social Skills Training;Health Status

title: Causal beliefs about depression in depressed patients, clinical psychologists and lay persons
authors: Kuyken, Willem and Brewin, C. R. and Power, M. J. and Furnham, Adrian
abstract: Used a semi-structured interview schedule and rating scales to compare the nature and extent of the beliefs of 20 depressed patients (mean age 36.8 yrs), 25 clinical psychologists (mean age 36.6 yrs), and 49 lay persons (mean age 31.3 yrs) about the causes of depression. Depressed patients and nondepressed lay persons alike had relatively extensive beliefs about the causes of depression that were comparable to those held by clinical psychologists. However, depressed patients tended to endorse biological explanations of the causes of depression to a greater extent than clinical psychologists. In contrast, clinical psychologists assigned a more important causal role to unconscious processes and childhood vulnerability factors than did either depressed patients or nondepressed lay controls. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: beliefs about causes of depression;depressed patients vs clinical psychologists vs lay people;England;Major Depression;Mental Illness (Attitudes Toward);Client Attitudes;Psychologist Attitudes

title: Causal attributions in psychiatric patients.
journal: European archives of psychiatry and clinical neuroscience
authors: Hambrecht, M and Hohmann, M
abstract: An instrument for a systematic assessment of attributions that psychiatric patients have about their disorder is presented together with some preliminary results, for example on differences between sex and diagnostic groups. The comparison with a sample of (mostly untreated) students demonstrates that causal attributions in psychiatric patients should be assessed with specifically designed instruments. The presented scale may help to investigate longitudinally the course of causal attributions during treatment.

title: Causal beliefs of mental disorders and treatment preferences in Ghana
authors: Lamensdorf, Angela Mona-Liza

title: Causal Attributions and Post-Traumatic Stress in Adolescents.
journal: Journal of Child Psychology & Psychiatry & Allied Disciplines
authors: Joseph, Steve A. and Brewin, Chris R. and Yule, William and Williams, Ruth
abstract: The aim of the present study was to explore the relationship between causal attributions made by adolescent survivors of the Jupiter cruise ship sinking, and post-traumatic symptomatology in the year following disaster. Evidence is presented that more internal causal attributions for negative and uncontrollable events during the incident are associated with greater post-traumatic stress one year later. The findings are discussed with reference to an attributional model of shame. title: Gender differences in perceptions of cancer.
journal: Journal of cancer education : the official journal of the American Association for Cancer Education
authors: Murray, M and McMillan, C L
abstract: The purpose of this study was to consider gender differences in laypeople's beliefs about and explanations of cancer. Over 700 adults answered a questionnaire about their perceptions and explanations of the disease. The majority of respondents identified cancer as the most fearful disease. Women were more frightened of cancer than were men, whereas men were more frightened of heart disease than were women. The greatest fear of cancer was its perceived incurability and the associated suffering, whereas the greatest fear of heart disease was perceived susceptibility. Men were more likely than women to hold a more negative attitude toward cancer information. Factor analysis of the perceived causes of cancer identified four causal factors, which were labelled Stress, Environmental, Health-related, and Behavioural. Men were more likely to identify behavioural items as important whereas women were more likely to rate heredity as important. Fear of cancer was highly correlated with the health beliefs but not with the perceived causes of cancer. However, a regression analysis found that these health beliefs explained only a small proportion of the variance in cancer fear. The findings are discussed with reference to cancer education.
keywords: Attitude to Health*;Men/*psychology;Neoplasms/*psychology;Women/*psychology;Acquired Immunodeficiency Syndrome/psychology;Adolescent;Adult;Aged;80 and over;Fear;Female;Health Behavior;Health Education;Heart Diseases/psychology;Humans;Ireland;Male;Mental Disorders/psychology;Middle Aged;Neoplasms/etiology;Risk Factors;Sex

title: Prior contacts and perceptions of previously mentally disturbed patients
authors: Ogedengbe, R. O.
abstract: Explored the extent to which contacts with previously mentally disturbed patients (MDPs) influence how such individuals are perceived, by surveying 74 Nigerians who had had no contact with MDPs and 100 Nigerians who had had prior contact. It was hypothesized that Ss who have had contacts with MDPs (1) perceive such individuals more favorably than do those without prior contacts and (2) perceive MDPs as more able to perform as normals. Among other questions, Ss were surveyed as to the perceived cause and prognosis of mental illness, as well as employment opportunities for former MDPs. The 2 hypotheses were supported. Certain inconsistencies were discovered in the responses of those who had some form of contacts with former MDPs. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: prior contact;perceptions of previously mentally disturbed patients;patients' significant others vs townspeople;Nigeria;Adult;Attitude to Health;Causality;Cultural Characteristics;Health Education;Humans;Interpersonal Relations;Male;Mental Disorders;Prognosis;Sampling Studies;Social Behavior;Socioeconomic Factors;Surveys and Questionnaires;Familiarity;Mental Illness (Attitudes Toward);Psychiatric Patients;Social Perception;Adult Attitudes;Significant Others

title: Culturally relevant psychiatric care: The West Indian as a client
authors: Brent, June E. and Callwood, Gloria B.
abstract: Cultural sensitivity is essential to the provision of quality mental health intervention for West Indian clients. West Indian culture (including belief systems, family patterns, childrearing practices, racial mixtures, and geography) influences the presentation of and perceived causes of symptoms in mentally ill persons who are natives of the Eastern Caribbean Islands. Parenthood and childbearing beliefs and practices are discussed in relationship to their influences on the psychosocial development of the West Indian family. Salient cultural norms, mores, folkways, and habits are presented in relationship to the impact on clients presenting psychopathology. Cultural diversity requires the effective clinician to approach clients with an attitude of cultural relativity. Concerted effort on the clinician's part may be required to overcome egocentric feelings and behavior that could interfere with culturally relevant and effective intervention. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: cultural norms & mores & folkways & habits;cultural sensitivity psychiatric care of West Indian clients;clinicians;Blacks;Cultural Sensitivity;Psychiatry;Psychiatrists

title: Causal attributions for illness among Turkish psychiatric out-patients and differences between diagnostic groups
journal: Social Psychiatry and Psychiatric Epidemiology: The International Journal for Research in Social and Genetic Epidemiology and Mental Health Services
authors: Karanci, A. Nuray
abstract: 152 Turkish nonpsychotic psychiatric outpatients completed a 31-item questionnaire for attributions for psychological problems. The factor analysis of the responses yielded 7 factors: attributions to conflicts within the family of origin and the present family, attributions to personal-characterological and behavioral attributes, work problems, interpersonal conflicts, and bad luck. Examination of the causal attributions of patients from 3 diagnostic groups revealed no significant differences between diagnostic groups. The highest attributional scores were for conflicts with the present family and personal-characterological attributes. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2019 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: causal attributions for illness;1856 yr olds with anxiety vs somatoform vs depressive disorders;Turkey;Adolescent;Adult;Ambulatory Care;Conflict (Psychology);Employment;Female;Humans;Interpersonal Relations;Male;Mental Disorders;Middle Aged;Psychiatric Status Rating Scales;Anxiety Disorders;Attribution;Client Attitudes;Major Depression;Somatoform Disorders

title: The physical and psychological aftermath of rape - No safe haven:  Male violence against women at home, at work, and in the community.
authors: Koss, Mary P. and Goodman, Lisa A. and Browne, Angela and Fitzgerald, Louise F. and Keita, Gwendolyn Puryear and Russo, Nancy Felipe
abstract: Discusses the somatic and psychological consequences of rape. Somatic consequences include genital and nongential physical injuries and sexually transmitted diseases. Unreflected in reviews of acute consequences are those victims who present with delayed consequences and chronic illnesses such as pain disorders. Stress-related health effects are also discussed. Cognitive changes include the alteration of cognitive schema and the changes in the relationship of causal attributions to distress. Psychological symptoms are common and continue for many years after sexual assault; these symptoms include anxiety, depression, and lowered sexual functioning and satisfaction. The authors then focus on psychological models and constructs of the aftereffects of rape, such as the PTSD construct, and examine theoretical explanations for the creation of PTSD symptoms. Common themes and limitations of current models are discussed. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2020 APA, all rights reserved)

title: The ecology of support for caregiving families
journal: Journal of Developmental and Behavioral Pediatrics
authors: Cooley, W. Carl
abstract: Discusses factors influencing families' caregiving and coping responses to issues and troubles, focusing on the care of disabled family members. The need for societal sources of family support is emphasized, and changing attitudes toward family support services are discussed. Competencies that characterize resilient families include seeking a causal attribution for what has happened, regaining a sense of mastery over events and outcomes, and enhancing self esteem. Finally, a community based family center system of support is discussed, based on 3 subsystems: (1) a ring of natural support, including family and friends, (2) informal supports specific to the issue of caregiving for a family member with a disability, and (3) formal supports, such as insurance and respite care. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2020 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: stressors & societal sources of support;family caregivers of children with disabilities;Adaptation;Psychological;Adolescent;Caregivers;Child;Preschool;Community Mental Health Services;Crisis Intervention;Disabled Persons;Humans;Infant;Newborn;Social Isolation;Social Support;Family Members;Caregiving;Disorders;Stress

title: Comparison of a community dysthymia sample at screening with a matched group of nondepressed community controls
journal: Journal of Nervous and Mental Disease
authors: McCullough, James P. and McCune, Kathleen J. and Kaye, Arthur L. and Braith, James A. and Friend, Roxanne and Roberts, W. Christopher and Belyea-Caldwell, Susan and Norris, Sarah L. W. and Hampton, Christlanne
abstract: Compared the psychosocial functioning of an untreated, community sample of 24 Ss with Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders-III-Revised (DSM-III-R) dysthymia at screening (drawn from 96 1973 yr olds who responded by mail to newspaper advertisements soliciting depressed Ss) to that of a matched sample of 18 community nondepressed volunteers with no lifetime or current history of axis I disorders. Interviews and testing procedures revealed that Ss with dysthymia were less sociable (introversion) and clinically high on neuroticism/instability, external in regard to their causal attributions, less stable for positive uncontrollable events and more stable and global for negative uncontrollable events, relied more on coping strategies such as wishful thinking and self-blame, were more interpersonally submissive and hostile, and had a poorer social support-resource network. In addition, Ss with dysthymia reported more family dysfunction and a higher rate of negative major life events. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2020 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: psychosocial functioning;dysthymic 1973 yr olds;Adaptation;Psychological;Adult;Aged;Comorbidity;Depressive Disorder;Family;Female;Hostility;Humans;Internal-External Control;Introversion (Psychology);Life Change Events;Male;Middle Aged;Neurotic Disorders;Personality Inventory;Psychiatric Status Rating Scales;Social Adjustment;Social Support;Dysthymic Disorder;Emotional Adjustment;Social Functioning;Research Design

title: The effects of training in nonaversive behavior management on the attitudes and understanding of direct care staff
journal: Journal of Behavior Therapy and Experimental Psychiatry
authors: Berryman, Jennifer and Evans, Ian M. and Kalbag, Aparna
abstract: Evaluated the effects of 2 training programs on the knowledge and attitudes of nonprofessional direct care staff. One program covered traditional principles of behavior management, and the other program focused on the strategies and assumptions of the nonaversive approach. 83 Ss (aged 2157 yrs) who worked in residential services for patients with developmental disabilities and psychiatric disorders completed 1 of the 2 day-long training programs. Ss were observed as they designed and implemented a treatment program for a patient. Ss also completed measures of their causal attributions for challenging behavior and their attitudes toward disabled persons at baseline and at follow-up. Ss who received nonaversive training had a more sophisticated understanding of the range of possible causes of behavior and suggested treatments based on further functional analyses and teaching new skills. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: training in traditional vs nonaversive behavior management;attributions for challenging behavior & attitudes toward disabled;2157 yr old staff at residential care center;Adult;Attitude of Health Personnel;Aversive Therapy;Behavior Therapy;Curriculum;Female;Humans;Inservice Training;Intellectual Disability;Internal-External Control;Male;Mental Disorders;Middle Aged;Patient Care Team;Personality Assessment;Professional-Patient Relations;Social Environment;Aversion Therapy;Clinical Methods Training;Disabled (Attitudes Toward);Health Personnel Attitudes;Residential Care Institutions

title: Attributional locus of control, psychotherapeutic outcome and the evaluation of clients
authors: Otto, Laura Lee
abstract: In this examination of the potential effects of therapist orientation, attribution, and therapeutic outcome on client evaluation in the psychotherapeutic context, it was proposed that therapists tend to make causal attributions based on their therapeutic orientation (psychodynamic vs. cognitive-behavioral), perceptions of the key actors in the situation (client vs. others), and outcome of the situation (success vs. failure to achieve progress in therapy). In addition, client evaluations were thought to be related to therapists' attributions for cause. Experienced psychotherapists (N = 250) evaluated the mental health of a client presented in one of eight case studies, in which client outcome and locus of control for cause of outcome were varied. No differences in attributional style were found between psychodynamic and cognitive-behavior therapists. Therapists were more likely to take credit for successful therapeutic interventions than for situations in which a client has not made progress in therapy; under these conditions, therapists' evaluations of clients were related to their perceptions of client responsibility for outcome. The implications of these findings for psychotherapy and attribution theory were discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: therapist orientation & causal attribution & psychotherapeutic outcomes;client evaluation;experienced psychotherapists;Attribution;Clinical Judgment (Not Diagnosis);Psychotherapeutic Outcomes;Psychotherapeutic Processes;Psychotherapists;Clients;Internal-External Control

title: Clinical features and psychosocial factors in young adults with genital herpes
authors: Swanson, Janice M. and Dibble, Suzanne L. and Chenitz, W. Carole
abstract: Examined clinical features of genital herpes and perceived causes of recurrences and compared psychosocial factors in 70 young adults (aged 1835 yrs) with genital herpes to normative data populations. Ss completed the Genital Herpes Questionnaire and measures of depression, self-concept, stress, and distress. Stress, menstruation, overextension, and sexual intercourse were the primary perceived causes of recurrence. Stress symptoms reported most frequently included headaches, irritability and anger, and fatigue. Compared to normative populations, Ss had lower self-concepts, more psychopathology, more daily hassles, and less intense uplifts. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
