title: Colonizing the insane: Causes of insanity in the Cape, 18911920
authors: Swartz, Sally
abstract: Evolutionary theory, capturing and then proliferating the idea of higher and lower life forms, primitive and civilized races, was strongly implicated in the political, economic and social policies of the British colonial practice, because it provided a perfect rationalization for the assertion that Whites were superior to Blacks, and would only remain so if the living habits of Whites were strictly policed in order to prevent backslide to savagery. As a site of colonialization, the Cape Colony therefore provides fertile ground for the discussion of psychiatric ideas about intersections between 'race' and 'insanity.' Causes of mental disorder as a discourse on besieged colonials and their confrontation with Black Otherness can be traced in the etiological categories used in Cape asylum statistical tables during the period 18911909, and also in attributions of causes commonly ascribed to White and Black patients. This article compares perceived causes of mental disorder in White and Black lunatics, drawing on the statistical tables of the Valkenberg and Fort Beaufort Asylums. Case-studies taken from Valkenberg records for the period 18911920 are used to illustrate ways in which scientific theory and colonial experience were textualized in asylum doctors' writing. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: intersections between race & insanity & the causes of insanity during the British colonization period of the Cape Town;case studies from Valkenberg & Fort Beaufort Asylums;18911920;Commitment (Psychiatric);Involuntary Treatment;Mental Disorders;Psychiatric Hospitals;Racial and Ethnic Differences;Blacks;History;Race and Ethnic Discrimination;Social Processes;Whites

title: Seeking help for premenstrual syndrome: Women's self-reports and treatment preferences
authors: Hunter, Myra S. and Swann, Catherine and Ussher, Jane M.
abstract: Explored the perceptions and beliefs of 44 women who were seeking help for PMS. Ss completed a questionnaire about their experience with PMS, their beliefs about its cause, and about past and possible future treatment for PMS. Ss seeking help for PMS reported a significantly higher level of depressed mood and anxiety than a family planning control sample of 88 women. Ratings of depressed mood and anxiety were unrelated to menstrual cycle stage at the time of questionnaire completion, suggesting that many Ss were experiencing generalized distress. Both psychological and hormonal causal attributions were acknowledged, and the women expressed preferences for both psychological and hormonal treatments from the clinic. A biopsychosocial model is advocated in the assessment and treatment of women who seek help for self-reported PMS. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: self reported symptoms & attributions;psychological & hormonal treatment preferences;female 1550 yr olds seeking treatment for PMS;England;application of biopsychosocial model;Client Attitudes;Hormone Therapy;Mental Health Services;Premenstrual Syndrome;Biopsychosocial Approach;Human Females

title: Locus of responsibility, perceived dangerousness, and just world beliefs as predictors of reported willingness to help homeless persons
authors: Kincaid, Margaret Mary
abstract: The purpose of the present study was to determine to what extent attitudinal variables and demographic characteristics of respondents predict reported willingness to help subgroups of homeless persons. Participants included 291 (64% female and 36% male) predominantly (88%) Caucasian adult college students with a mean age of 38 years. Participants completed a packet that included a demographic questionnaire, the Modified Attitudes Toward Homeless Persons Scale, the Just World Beliefs Scale, a rank ordering of the perceived causes of homelessness, and the Marlowe-Crowne Social Desirability Scale (including items specific to homeless persons). Criterion variables were reported overall willingness to help homeless persons and subgroups of homeless persons who were presented as being displaced, as having mental illness problems, or as having substance abuse problems. Predictor variables included locus of responsibility beliefs, just world beliefs, perceived dangerousness of homeless persons, and demographic items. Mental illness and substance abuse were endorsed as the most common causes of homelessness. Participants reported a greater willingness to help displaced homeless persons (t = 8.21, p <1) and mentally ill homeless persons (t = 8.38, p <1) than homeless persons with substance abuse problems, however did not differ in their willingness to help the former subgroups (t =.17, p >). Of the 52% of the variance accounted for in reported overall willingness to help homeless persons, perceived dangerousness accounted for 36% and locus of responsibility accounted for approximately 15% of the variance. Just world beliefs did not add a significant predictive contribution. Separate regression analyses found that political orientation was the best single demographic predictor, accounting for 20% of the variance in overall willingness to help. There was a main effect for locus of responsibility (Rao's R = 35.89, p <1) and for perceived dangerousness (Rao' (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: locus of responsibility & perceived dangerousness & just world beliefs & demographic characteristics;willingness to help homeless persons;college students (mean age 38 yrs.);Assistance (Social Behavior);Dangerousness;Demographic Characteristics;Responsibility;World View;Homeless

title: Causal attribution processes among the Chinese - The handbook of Chinese psychology.
authors: Crittendon, Kathleen S. and Bond, Michael Harris
abstract: reviews the research literature on attibutional phenomena and their consequences and antecedents among individuals of Chinese ancestry and culture / phenomena of interest will include attributions concerning the causes of events and behaviour, and enduring attibutional styles / the review covers conceptual issues, strategies for measuring attribution patterns, cross-cultural comparisons of the patterns seen in Chinese samples with those of other groups, and evidence concerning consequences of attributional processes for achievement motivation and behaviour, emotions, mental health, social identities, and strategies for resolving interpersonal conflict / a self-presentational perspective suggests that attributional patterns vary across sociocultural contexts  cross-cultural comparisons of causal attribution patterns [comparisons using H. M. Lefcourt's Causality Scale, comparisons using the Attributional Style Questionnaire, cross-cultural comparisons using other measurement strategies] (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2020 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: Self Psychology

title: Conceptions of mental illness, its causal attributions, and the help-seeking attitudes of Soviet Jewish immigrants
authors: Fruchtbaum, Irene S.
abstract: Conceptions of mental illness and their perceived causes were investigated as they relate to help-seeking attitudes of Soviet Jewish immigrants. The purpose of this study was to gain a better understanding of the factors that may contribute to the reported underuse of professional mental-health services by this group of immigrants. Data were gathered in two stages. First, a questionnaire using a vignette format, a questionnaire on general conceptions of mental illness, and a demographic questionnaire were administered to 222 Soviet Jewish immigrants residing in Los Angeles, California and Houston, Texas, to assess participants' causal attributions, the perceived helpfulness of various types of assistance and assistance providers, and general conceptions of mental illness, and to elicit some demographic information. The second stage included 12 semi-structured interviews with Soviet immigrants to further explore the subjects of the study. The results indicated that Soviet Jewish immigrants attribute mental illness mainly to social causes related to the changes in life situation and to social and environmental pressures. Causal attributions of mental illness were the most significant predictors of corresponding types of mental-health attitudes of the participants in this study. Participants' choices of mental-health assistance for themselves were significantly different from their preferences for psychological types of assistance for others. Participants placed their primary reliance on self or family and friends where mental problems are concerned. The belief that mental health is maintained by the avoidance of morbid thoughts was related to the notion of the importance of self-help. There were no significant gender differences found in the participants' responses. Based on the results of this study, the main barriers to use of mental-health services for Soviet immigrants appear to be the use of alternative, non-professional resources as social supports and probab (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: conceptions of mental illness & its causal attributions;help-seeking attitudes;Soviet Jewish immigrants;US;Causal Analysis;Help Seeking Behavior;Immigration;Jews;Mental Disorders;Asians;Whites;Causality;Emigrants and Immigrants

title: Psychological health of Gulf War-era military personnel
authors: Stretch, Robert H. and Bliese, Paul D. and Marlowe, David and Wright, Kathleen M.
abstract: Assessed the effects of the Persian Gulf War on the psychological health and adjustment of military personnel in Hawaii and Pennsylvania, 1,524 of whom did and 2,512 of whom did not deploy to the Persian Gulf during Operations Desert Shield/Desert Storm. Ss anonymously completed a questionnaire providing information on demographics, psychological and psychosocial health, deployment stressors, current life problems, current distress, and causal attributions of present problems. Deployed Ss experienced significant levels of stress during deployment and continued to report significant stress in their present lives. Although deployed Ss' scores on the Brief Symptom Inventory were high compared with those of civilian nonpatients, their scores were essentially identical to those of nondeployed Ss. Although considerable stress was experienced, most Ss were handling it unremarkably. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2020 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: psychological & psychosocial health & current stressors & causal attributions of current problems;military personnel deployed vs not deployed during Persian Gulf War;Adult;Aerospace Medicine;Female;Humans;Iraq;Male;Military Personnel;Naval Medicine;Psychological Tests;Regression Analysis;Stress;Psychological;Surveys and Questionnaires;United States;Warfare;Adjustment;Mental Health;War;Attribution;Military Deployment;Social Health

title: Basic behavioral science research for mental health: Social influence and social cognition
abstract: Discusses the issues of social influence, social cognition, stereotyping and prejudice, and social and personal identity in basic behavioral science research for mental health. The significance of social influence for mental and physical health is illustrated by 3 lines of research: impact of persuasive messages, self-persuasion, and resisting pressure to change or conform. Three aspects of social cognition, including accessibility of social beliefs, causal attribution, and standards of self-evaluation, are given, and the prevalence of stereotyping is discussed. The significance of both social and personal identity in mental health is addressed, as well as  the issue of coping with challenges to the identity. Directions for future research on social influence and social cognition are outlined. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2020 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: issues of social influence & cognition & stereotyping & prejudice & social & personal identity in basic behavioral science research for mental health;Behavioral Sciences;Cognition;Humans;Mental Health;Prejudice;Research;Stereotyping;Experimentation;Social Cognition;Social Influences;Social Sciences;Self-Concept;Social Identity;Stereotyped Attitudes

title: Confirmation versus disconfirmation of gender based expectations regarding the expression of psychological dysfunction: Effect on perception of psychological health and causal attribution
authors: Killian, Nancy E.
abstract: The current study investigated the effect of confirmation and disconfirmation of gender based expectations about psychopathology on perception of psychological health, and on the causes ascribed to psychopathological behaviors (causal attributions). Participants were 245 male and female college students, who had resided in the United States since age 12, and were unfamiliar with psychopathology. Based on a theoretical model proposed by Deaux (1976), the current study hypothesized that the causes ascribed to psychopathological behaviors would be affected by the confirmation and disconfirmation of gender based expectations about psychopathology. Furthermore, it was hypothesized that perception of psychological health would be affected by the causal attribution processes explicated in Deaux's model. The experimental manipulation was vignettes that described male, female, and sex unspecified actors with psychopathological behaviors that were male linked (associated with males), female linked (associated with females), and gender neutral (associated equally with males and females). Participants assumed the role of a counselor, and evaluated the psychological health of actors, using the Psychological Health Scale, an instrument derived from the Health Sickness Rating Scale (Luborsky 1962, 1975). Participants also rated the cause of the dysfunctional behaviors on locus of causality (dispositional-situational), and stability (stable-unstable) dimensions, using two subscales of the Causal Dimension Scale (Russell, 1982). For the hypotheses to be supported, an interaction between gender linkage of the psychopathological behaviors and sex of the actor would have to be obtained. However, statistical analyses did not reveal an interaction, therefore the hypotheses were not supported. It was concluded that, while the psychologically dysfunctional behaviors, used in the current study, contained both gender and psychopathological components, gender linkage was overwhelmed by the p (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: confirmation vs disconfirmation of gender based expectations on expression of psychological dysfunction;perception of psychological health & causal attribution;college students;Attribution;Expectations;Human Sex Differences;Psychopathology;Psychological Development;Causality

title: Mental health and the Asian communities: A local survey
authors: Hatfield, Barbara and Mohamad, Hadi and Rahim, Zakia and Tanweer, Hussain
abstract: Interviewed 106 people from the Asian communities in a British town to determine attitudes toward and use of mental health services. Ss were from Indian, Pakistani, and East African Asian backgrounds. Personal and social stresses of the group were explored, as were their perceptions of the causes of mental illness and appropriate responses. Although most people saw family and social stress as central, a religious dimension was also prominent, in terms both of causes and treatment of mental illness. There was no evidence of rejection of mainstream services. A lack of knowledge of service availability was apparent, with a heavy reliance on GP services for mental health care in the community. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Psychiatric disorder and the development of a causal belief questionnaire
authors: Whittle, Peter
abstract: Describes the development of a questionnaire designed to assess causal beliefs held by clients for the onset of their psychiatric disorders. A range of possible causes was elicited from clients, clinical staff and members of the public. These were arranged in a questionnaire form and administered to a sample of 113 psychiatric clients who were asked to express their beliefs regarding the causes of their own disorders. Factor analysis yielded 4 factors reflecting 'Psychosocial', 'Biological', 'Structural' and 'Stress' beliefs. The efficacy of this questionnaire as a tool for understanding the causal beliefs held by clients and other family members is considered. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: development of questionnaire on causal beliefs about disorder onset;psychiatric patients;Attribution;Mental Disorders;Onset (Disorders);Questionnaires;Test Construction;Psychiatric Patients;Causality

title: Die Bedeutung der Konzepte zu Krankheitsursachen und Behandlungserwartungen in der ersten Behandlungsphase = The significance of illness attribution concepts and treatment expectations in the initial treatment phase
authors: Adler, Yvik and Rauchfleisch, Udo and Mllejans, Ruth
abstract: Studied the role of illness-related causal attributions (IRCAs) and treatment expectations (TEs) in determining therapeutic processes and outcomes during the initial phase of outpatient psychotherapy. Human Ss: 56 male and female Swiss adults (aged 1869 yrs) (outpatients) (mixed psychiatric disorders). 19 normal male and female Swiss adults (psychotherapists). During the initial clinical interview, all Ss completed questionnaires assessing their IRCAs and TEs. Results from the patients and their therapists were compared and analyzed in relation to treatment process and outcome data. Correlations between the patients' personality and biographical characteristics and the IRCAs and TEs of both patients and therapists were analyzed, and changes in the patients' IRCAs after the 5th therapy session were determined. Tests used: The Illness Concept Questionnaire (F. G. Plaum, 1968) and the Giessen Test (D. Beckmann et al, 1991). (English abstract) (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Subjektive Krankheitstheorien bei Patienten einer psychotherapeutischen Ambulanz
journal: Zeitschrift fr Klinische Psychologie, Psychiatrie und Psychotherapie
authors: Faller, Hermann
abstract: Investigated 195 psychotherapy outpatients' (age 1867 yrs) causal attributions toward illness, using a self-report questionnaire. Items rated highest included: inner conflicts, inner anxieties, not being able to cope with problems, lack of self-assertion, and problems in partnership or family. The least supported attributions were sensitivity to climate and sensitivity to pollution. Factor analysis yielded 4 dimensions of attributions: intrapsychic causes, interpersonal causes, social causes, and somatic causes. Ss' attributions differed with age, gender, education level, and type of disorder (e.g., somatoform, depressive, eating disorders). Therapists judged the relationship with their patients as better with Ss who were more likely to favor intrapsychic and less likely to favor somatic causes. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2018 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: age & sex & education level & disorder & therapeutic relationship causal attributions toward illness;1867 yr old psychotherapy outpatients;Attribution;Demographic Characteristics;Mental Disorders;Mental Illness (Attitudes Toward);Psychotherapeutic Processes;Age Differences;Educational Attainment Level;Human Sex Differences;Psychotherapy

title: Minority help-seeking: Reply
journal: Journal of the American Academy of Child & Adolescent Psychiatry
authors: Weisz, John R. and McMiller, William P.
abstract: Replies to comments by C. O. Toppelberg (see record 84-27710) on the authors' (see record 84-16853) study of help-seeking for child mental health problems among minorities, specifically regarding the issue of language barriers. The authors respond that language is one of many factors which much be researched to explain differences between ethnic groups in patterns of help-seeking; other cultural factors (i.e., the family's causal attributions for the disorder, and views about taking issues outside the family) may also be relevant. The purpose of the original study was to provide a foundation, to determine those ethnic differences in help-seeking which need to be explained further. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: help seeking from agencies & professionals vs family & community for child's mental health problems;African American vs Latino vs White families;commentary reply;Family;Health Care Seeking Behavior;Language Proficiency;Mental Health Services;Racial and Ethnic Differences;Blacks;Communities;Minority Groups;Outreach Programs;Whites;Latinos/Latinas

title: Learned helplessness or expectancy-value? A psychological model for describing the experiences of different categories of unemployed people
authors: Rodrguez, Yol and a Garca
abstract: Proposes a model that assumes the relationships between unemployment and expectation of success, commitment to work, motivation, causal attributions, self-esteem and depression are moderated by (a) whether or not the unemployed individual is seeking a first job and (b) age. It is proposed that for the unemployed who are seeking their first job (seekers) the relationship among these variables will be consistent with expectancy-value theory, but for those who have had a previous job (losers), the relationships will be more consistent with learned helplessness theory. It is further assumed that within this latter group the 'young losers' will experience universal helplessness whereas the 'adult losers' will experience personal helplessness. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2022 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: job search & age in model of learned helplessness & expectancy-value theories perspective on unemployment & psychological health;adults seeking 1st job vs those who lost previous job;Age Differences;Expectations;Learned Helplessness;Mental Health;Unemployment;Employment Status;Individual Differences;Models, Psychological;Helplessness, Learned

title: Childhood sexual abuse: An investigation of its impact on children's coping, self-efficacy, emotion regulation and perceptions of self and others
authors: Thompson, Lori Bast Ann
abstract: Sexually abused children frequently exhibit little or no psychiatric symptomatology when assessed during childhood, but it is important to examine what other consequences may result from the abuse, as sexual abuse is thought to be a major risk factor for a variety of adult mental health problems. It is possible that experiencing sexual abuse adversely effects important areas of children's functioning which contribute to the development of psychopathology later in life. The purpose of this study is to examine four areas of children's functioning, including coping, perceptions of helplessness, emotion regulation, and self-concept, in a group of twenty-two sexually abused, twenty-five psychiatric control, and twenty-seven normal control females between the ages of 6 and 12. Using teacher report (The Child Behavior Checklist: Teacher Rating Form), results replicated previous findings of parental reports which indicate that sexually abused children are perceived as experiencing more psychological difficulties than a normal population but fewer difficulties than those manifested by nonsexually abused child psychiatric outpatient populations. Furthermore, results from a projective measure, designed to indirectly assess trauma-related schemas, revealed that compared to a normal control group, sexually abused females have significantly more negative perceptions of themselves and others. Although sexually abused children also demonstrated more negative self concept on a self-report measure (the Piers-Harris Self-Concept Scale), these differences were not statistically significant. No significant differences between groups were found in regard to coping skills, as assessed by the Coping Scale for Children and Youth, or learned helplessness, as assessed by the Causal Attribution Measure. Significant differences were found in emotion regulation skills, as assessed by the Emotion Regulation Q-sort. However, results were against this study's predictions. The psychiatric control group demonstrated significantly more impaired emotion regulation skills when compared to the sexually abused children. The fact that sexually abused children demonstrate more negative perceptions of themselves and others has long-term implications for their development of appropriate interpersonal relationships, and their ability to utilize support networks during times of distress. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: Childhood sexual abuse: An investigation of its impact on children's coping;self-efficacy;emotion regulation and perceptions of self and others;Coping Behavior;Emotional Control;Self-Efficacy;Self-Perception;Sexual Abuse;Sex Offenses

title: Psychological affliction and mental illness among Maya Indians of Highland Chiapas, Mexico
authors: Castille, Dorothy Marie
abstract: For the Tzeltal and Tzotzil speaking populations of Highland Chiapas, Mexico three specific conditions--jowiel 'aggressive madness', chawaj 'dizziness and disorientation', and tup' tup' ik' 'seizures'--are grouped together on the basis of behavioral criteria and symptom reports and defined as mental illness. This dissertation examines the experience and diagnosis of mental disorders for the Tzeltal Maya of Chiapas, Mexico. The methods employed include focused ethnoepidemiology survey, folk medical explanatory model survey, and recruitment of self-identified cases of recognized folk disorders--to provide a study population of cases for the administration of life history interviews, folk explanatory model questionnaire for the history of current condition, and video taping of interviews. The data reported on here reflect the self-diagnosed and reported health status of 1986 living individuals from 306 households in the Tzeltal Maya municipality of Tenejapa. Of those interviewed, approximately 100 individuals reported some illness, with 34 individuals reporting current or previous mental illness: 20 report chawaj, 5 report suffering from jowiel, 7 from tup' tup' ik', and 2 recount suffering from some other mental illness. The 'other' mental illnesses are headaches, sometimes classified as mental illness. Of the 33 individuals suffering from some type of mental illness, 21 females and 12 males comprise the population, or two-thirds women and one-third men. They range in age from an infant of 5 months old to a couple of elderly men of approximately 80 years old, males from 5 months to 82 years and women from 7 to 72 years of age. The indigenous taxomonic criteria for a differential diagnosis appears to be based on similarity of symptoms and distinguished through severity of expressed behavior over time. Of the three, tup' tup' ik' is the condition with the clearest biomedical concordance and the most treatable and avoidable Sufferers accounts of their experiences with these health conditions underscore the role of culture in the self-perceived cause and expression of illness. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: experience & self-diagnosis of mental disorders & health status;0.482 yr old Tzeltal Maya Indian males & 772 yr old Tzeltal Maya Indian females;Mexico;Health;Mental Disorders;Racial and Ethnic Groups;Self-Evaluation;Mentally Ill Persons

title: Hopelessness responding following negative feedback in African-American and Anglo-American college students and its relationship with personality and contextual variables
authors: De Arellano, Michael Andrew
abstract: Research on the mental health of ethnic minorities has increased notably in the past two decades in an attempt to develop more culturally sensitive and appropriate interventions. Within the depression research literature, one of the theoretical frameworks which has been proposed for conceptualizing the etiology, maintenance, and treatment of depression is the 'learned helplessness' model (Abramson, Seligman, & Teasdale, 1978) and its reformulated 'hopelessness' model (Abramson, Metalsky, & Alloy, 1989; Alloy, Abramson, Metalsky, & Hartlage, 1988). The recent revisions of this model propose a diathesis-stress interaction in which individuals who engage in depressogenic causal attributions and make negative inferences about themselves and outcomes in response to stressful life events are predisposed to developing 'hopelessness depression' (Abramson et al., 1989). The present study examined how African-American and Anglo-American college students demonstrated differences in hopelessness responses to negative feedback in achievement-skills and social-skills related tasks. In addition, the extent to which group differences in hopelessness responding could be accounted for by personality and contextual variables that differed significantly between ethnic groups was assessed. Contrary to predictions, findings revealed that African-Americans demonstrated less hopelessness (i.e., less decrease in task self-efficacy) for the achievement-skills task than did Anglo-Americans. However, contextual and personality variables measured in this study did not account for the group differences. Possible explanations for these findings and implications for future research are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: personality & contextual variables;hopelessness response to negative feedback in achievement & social skills;African-American vs Anglo-American college students;Feedback;Hopelessness;Personality Traits;Racial and Ethnic Differences;Responses;African Americans

title: Staff disbeliefs about the challenging behaviors of children and adults  with mental retardation
authors: Hastings, Richard P.
abstract: From both theoretical and practical perspectives, staff beliefs are likely to have a significant impact on the process of care for children and adults with mental retardation who engage in challenging behaviors. This paper reviews research addressing 3 domains of staff beliefs: definitions of challenging behavior, causal attributions, and beliefs about appropriate intervention. In general, staff definitions were found to be at odds with formal definitions. According to care staff challenging behaviors are actions that are difficult to manage. Staff causal attributions appear congruent with current theory, when measured with little specificity. However, when staff are asked to suggest causes of challenging behavior with clearly described functions they often fail to make appropriate attributions. Beliefs about appropriate short-term interventions suggest responses likely to develop and/or maintain challenging behavior, but beliefs about longer-term planned intervention appear to be more closely matched to contemporary practice. Reasons for this long-term/short-term distinction, based on the demands of the immediate situation, are proposed. Suggestions for future research on staff beliefs are discussed in detail. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2020 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: definitions of & causal attributions about challenging behavior & beliefs about intervention for children & adults with mental retardation;mental health staff;Adult;Attitude of Health Personnel;Behavior Therapy;Child;Humans;Inservice Training;Intellectual Disability;Patient Care Planning;Social Behavior Disorders;Treatment Outcome;Attribution;Behavior Problems;Mental Health Personnel;Treatment;Health Personnel Attitudes;Intellectual Development Disorder;Intellectual Development Disorder (Attitudes Toward);Only Child

title: Measuring staff perceptions of challenging behaviour: the Challenging Behaviour Attributions Scale (CHABA).
journal: Journal of intellectual disability research : JIDR
authors: Hastings, R P
abstract: Causal attributions may interact with other variables to determine staff responses to challenging behaviour. Furthermore, staff perceptions of the causes of challenging behaviour are likely to change as a result of theoretical and practical training. However, there is no established simple method for measuring staff attributions that could facilitate research in these areas. The present paper describes the development and preliminary psychometric analysis of the Challenging Behaviour Attributions Scale (CHABA).
keywords: Health Personnel*;Judgment*;Mental Health Services*;Psychological Tests*;Conduct Disorder/*diagnosis;Adult;Conduct Disorder/psychology;Humans;Professional-Patient Relations

title: Mental illness and immigration - Handbook of immigrant health.
authors: Gaines, Atwood D. and Loue, Sana
abstract: A large number of disorders, seen as psychiatric from the perspective of US or other professional medicine, are to be found in countries around the world. Any and all of these may appear in the context of immigration. This chapter has (1) shown how Western psychiatry would perceive causes of mental disorders in immigrant populations and (2) presented some locally constructed mental disorders and how these might be (mis)interpreted by professional Western, largely US, psychiatrists.  Topics discussed include: introduction: immigrants and ethnopsychiatry (the immigrant experience, immigration and ethnopsychiatry, problem recognition, questions of Western psychiatric nosological universality, from perspective to illness); the problem of diagnosis in the West; sources disorders: views from the West (stress and complexity, psychological disorder and stigmatization, acculturation, physical deprivation and trauma, problems of communication); and non-Western constructions of illness. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2020 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: Mentally Ill Persons;Emigrants and Immigrants;Emigration and Immigration

title: Parental Attributions of the Causes of Their Children's Behavior.
authors: Jenson, Cary E. and Green, Robert G. and Singh, Nirbhay N. and Best, Al M. and Ellis, Cynthia R.
abstract: We investigated causal attributions parents made regarding their children's best and worst behavior while the children were taking methylphenidate (MPH) for Attention-Deficit Hyperactivity Disorder (ADHD). Twenty-six parents were surveyed each week for six weeks using the Parent Attribution Scale-Revised. This scale measures parents' attributions of the causes for their children's behavior when taking MPH to treat symptoms of ADHD. When attributing causes for best behavior, the parents rated their children's effort most often followed by their own effort and the positive medication effects. When attributing causes for worst behavior, the parents rated their children's lack of effort most often followed by inadequate medication effects and their own lack of effort. Our study suggests that parents rate effort most often when making attributions for their children's best and worst behavior. When making attributions for best behavior only, parents saw no difference between their own effor)

title: The relationship of attributions and expressed emotion to outcome and marital satisfaction in patients with bipolar disorder
authors: Greene, Lori Isman
abstract: Bipolar disorder is a mental illness marked by episodes of mania or hypomania and episodes of depression. Its cyclical patterns make it likely to impact and be impacted by marital relationships. The course of this illness may be affected by cognitive factors (i.e., the causal attributions made by patients and their spouses to explain events) and family factors (i.e., spouse expressed emotion/criticality). The purpose of this study was to investigate the relationship that causal attributions have with marital distress, spouse critical comments, and symptom outcome in patients with bipolar disorder. Participants were recruited from the New York Hospital-Cornell Medical Center and included 39 couples with one individual with bipolar disorder. They completed interviews, videotaped interactions, and self-report questionnaires measuring spouse criticality, symptomology, attributions, and marital distress. Results indicated that more distressed patients with bipolar disorder made more internal attributions to their spouses for negative events. Additionally, more critical spouses made more internal attributions to the patients for negative events and less internal attributions to themselves for negative events. Finally, although patient attribution variables did not predict symptom outcome, it was found that the more internal to patient, external to self, and stable the attributions for negative events made by the spouses, the more symptoms displayed by the patients at the end of 10 months of treatment. Implications of the current research are that spousal attributions were related to patient symptom outcome and should be addressed in cognitively based marital therapy. Additional research examining the extent to which attributions can be effectively modified as a result of psychotherapy, and exactly what impact that may have on the course of illness, is required. Other directions for future research as well as limitations of the current study are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: causal attributions & expressed emotion & symptom outcome & marital satisfaction;patients with bipolar disorder & their spouses;Attribution;Bipolar Disorder;Expressed Emotion;Marital Satisfaction;Patient Satisfaction

title: American Indians and mental health: Issues in psychiatric assessment and diagnosis - Cross cultural psychiatry.
authors: Norton, Ilena M. and Herrera, John M. and Lawson, William B. and Sramek, John J.
abstract: Describes issues that arise in the psychiatric diagnostic assessment of American Indian patients. Begins with a description of the American Indian and Alaska Native populations, followed by specific clinical examples to illustrate how American Indian cultural values and orientations influence the patients' presentation of illness, using the framework of the cultural formulation in Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders-IV (DSM-IV). Particular attention is given to those sections of the cultural formulation that relate to diagnosis. These include the predominant idioms of distress, perceived causes of illness or the explanatory models, and the meaning and perceived severity of the individual's symptoms in relation to norms of the cultural reference group. (PsycInfo Database Record (c) 2021 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: Indians, North American

title: The influence of causal attributions on the psychological adjustment of post-treatment adolescent cancer survivors
authors: Halperin, Jane Carol
abstract: The aims of this study were to determine whether or not post-treatment adolescent cancer survivors (ACS) make causal attributions when confronted by a cancer diagnosis, the nature of those attributions, and whether or not those attributions are associated with psychological adjustment. The causal attributions of thirty-four ACS (23 males, 11 females), ranging in age from 12-20 years (M = 16.3, SD = 2.3) were elicited by semi-structured interview and rated for causal source (internal vs. external) and causal controllability (controllable vs. uncontrollable) using an adaptation of the Content Analysis of Verbatim Explanations method (Schulman, Castellon, & Seligman, 1988). Psychological adjustment was measured by the Mental Health Inventory (MHI). Social desirability was evaluated by the Crowne and Marlowe Social Desirability Scale. One-way ANOVAS were used to evaluate the relationship between causal variables and MHI scores. Multiple regression models were used to evaluate sociodemographic characteristics and illness-related factors for potential effects. The findings confirm that ACS, like adults, begin an attributional search when faced with a diagnosis of cancer. Ninety-one percent of participants reported asking themselves 'Why me?' and 90% specified personal theories. ACS gave a broad range of reasons why they got cancer, most commonly citing environmental exposures and heredity. The majority of adolescents attributed their cancers to external and uncontrollable causes. There were no statistically significant differences based on the causal source or causal controllability variables. The participants were psychologically well-adjusted, with MHI scores comparable to the normative sample. Age, in the context of other sociodemographics, had a significant effect on the relationship between causal attributions and psychological adjustment Older adolescents were relatively more distressed than younger adolescents. Illness-related factors were not significant predictors for this group of ACS. Social desirability response set did not affect MHI variables. The findings support Abramson, Seligman, and Teasdale's (1978) reformulation of the learned helplessness model that external causes are associated with better psychological outcomes for illness events. If the association between external/uncontrollable attributions and adjustment is borne out by future research, then clinicians could profitably focus on reframing adolescents' attributions, when necessary, to causes which are perceived as outside of oneself and beyond one's control. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: causal attributions;psychological adjustment;1220 yr old post-treatment adolescent cancer survivors (mean age 16.3 yrs);Adolescent Psychology;Attribution;Emotional Adjustment;Neoplasms;Survivors;Adolescent;Adaptation, Psychological

title: Children's attributions of their severely mentally ill parent's symptomatic behavior: A retrospective study
authors: Bourke, Andrew Benjamin
abstract: This dissertation study examined the causal attributions made by 30 adult children for their severely mentally ill parent's symptomatic behaviors. A retrospective methodology was used in order to explore the development of attributions from their first realization that their parent was behaving in a problematic manner to the present time. This study also explored the associations between attributions and participants' levels of coping and resiliency, as defined by their present functioning. The results of this study lend support to the use of an attributional framework in the study of children of the mentally ill. The data gathered using the Adult Children of the Mentally Ill-Attribution Scale (ACMI-AS) indicated reasonable internal consistency and expected intercorrelations of the attribution stems. A factor analysis of participants' responses to the ACMI-AS revealed three factors, including Internal to Self, Internal to Parent and Predictability. The data suggested that participants' attributions significantly changed from their initial realization of parental symptomatic behavior to the present time. The analysis indicated that maturity was not wholly responsible for the change in attributions. Rather, the subjective amount of information concerning mental illness as well as extra-familial support were significant contributing factors. The analyses between attributions and coping as well as between attributions and resiliency suggested a relationship between these variables. The data further suggested that attributions for parental control of the symptomatic behavior or personal control by the child were associated with increased psychopathology and lower self-esteem and self-efficacy in respondents. Attributions that highlighted predictability, external causation, and biological causation were associated with fewer somatic complaints and increased social self-efficacy. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: attributions of severely mentally ill parent's symptomatic behavior;levels of coping & resiliency;adult children of severely mentally ill;Attribution;Coping Behavior;Mental Disorders;Parents;Resilience (Psychological);Retrospective Studies;Only Child;Child

title: Beliefs and knowledge about aetiology of mental illness among Nigerian psychiatric patients and their relatives.
journal: African journal of medicine and medical sciences
authors: Adebowale, T O and Ogunlesi, A O
abstract: A survey of 70 insightful clinically stable out-patients with functional psychotic disorders and 70 accompanying relatives was carried out. They were interviewed about their beliefs concerning the cause of the illness, and their awareness of other possible aetiological factors. Relevant sociodemographic and clinical information were also elicited. Twelve (17.1%) patients and relatives, respectively, gave "medical" causal explanations; 16 (22.9%) patients and 13 (18.6%) relatives gave "psychosocial" causal explanations; 27 (38.6%) patients and 38 (54.3%) relatives were "uncertain" about the cause of their/relatives' illness (X2 = 5.08; df = 3: P = 0.16). Relatives reported a greater relevance of "heredity" (X2 = 11.58; P = 0.0006) and "supernatural" factors (X2 = 4.72: P = 0.029) as other possible causal factors, than patients. Patients with previous psychiatric hospitalisation reported higher prevalence of "psychosocial" and "supernatural" causal beliefs than those without (X2 = 9.15; P = 0.027). Also, patients with "medical" causal belief reported better treatment compliance than those with other beliefs (P = 0.031). Among relatives, "psychosocial" causal belief in comparison with other beliefs was associated with a longer duration of treatment in the hospital (h = 8.29; P = 0.04). For patients, knowledge about possible causal role of "heredity was significantly more prevalent among male than female patients (X2 = 6.55; P = 0.01) and admission of possible "supernatural" causation was associated with education below the secondary level (X2 = 6.68; P = 0.008). For relatives, knowledge about possible causal role of brain dysfunction was associated with longer duration of treatment (u = 3.93; P = 0.047), and knowledge of possible causal role of "psychosocial" stress was associated with urban place of residence rather than rural (X2 = 10.52; P = 0.0012). For both patients and relatives, the most acceptable aetiological proposition was the "supernatural" while the least was "psychosocial". Findings revealed, among others, the widespread belief in "supernatural" causation of mental illness in patients/relatives. Some identified significant findings may be relevant in mental health education programme development.
keywords: Attitude to Health*;Health Knowledge;Attitudes;Practice*;Family/*psychology;Outpatients/*psychology;Psychotic Disorders/*etiology;Psychotic Disorders/*psychology;Adult;Causality;Educational Status;Female;Genetic Predisposition to Disease/genetics;Health Education;Humans;Magic/psychology;Male;Medicine;African Traditional;Needs Assessment;Nigeria;Outpatients/education;Residence Characteristics/statistics & numerical data;Rural Health;Sex Factors;Socioeconomic Factors;Stress;Psychological/complications;Surveys and Questionnaires;Urban Health

title: Anxiety, depression, and religiositya controlled clinical study
authors: Pfeifer, Samuel and Waelty, Ursula
abstract: This study had the goal of firstly exploring the interrelation of neuroticism and religiosity in clinically diagnosed patients compared with a group of healthy controls, and secondly, exploring differential aspects of positive or negative perceptions of religion in the individual. Measurements of religiosity and neuroticism were conducted in 44 patients (aged 1865 yrs) with affective, anxiety and personality disorders, and 45 healthy controls. In addition, a battery of questions regarding the interaction of religion and mental health was applied. There was no correlation between neuroticism and religiosity, neither in the patient nor in the control group. However, marked differences were found in causal attributions and religious experience between patients and healthy controls. Anxiety concerning sexuality, super-ego conflicts and childhood fears of God was primarily associated with neuroticism and not with religious commitment. Healthy Ss consented significantly more often to the statement that 'religion can make a person sick' than patients with affective and anxiety disorders, who experienced religion rather as support than as a burden. However, they perceived their illness-related problems as an obstacle to express their faith. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: neurosis & religiosity;patients with anxiety & affective disorders & personality disorders (aged 1865 yrs);Affective Disorders;Anxiety;Neurosis;Personality Disorders;Religiosity

title: Notes from Namibia: Assessing mental illness in a multicultural developing country
authors: Vranckx, Constant H.
abstract: Describes some of the challenges of conducting research on mental illness in a multicultural developing country. The experiences of a research team are presented. First, the authors describe the prevalence of schizophrenia in a northwestern region of Namibia. They detail how standard methodologies, such as interviewing and counting of subjects, and discussion of mental symptoms and illness were profoundly affected by the cultural beliefs and practices of the study participants. The 2nd study was part of a larger survey of mental health needs in Namibia. This article describes what was learned about perceived causes of mental illness as determined by traditional influences and modern biomedical influences (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: conducting mental illness research;Namibia;Developed Countries;Experimentation;Mental Disorders;Developing Countries

title: Perceptions of mental and physical illnesses in north-western Ethiopia: Causes, treatments, and attitudes
authors: Mulatu, Mesfin Samuel
abstract: Explored causal beliefs about, perceived importance of various treatments for, and attitudes towards, 6 mental illnesses (schizophrenia, depression, anxiety disorder, alcoholism, and mental retardation) and 3 physical illnesses (tuberculosis, leprosy, and poliomyelitic paralysis) in 450 1770 yr olds from northwestern Ethiopia. Principal components analysis identified 4 meaningful illness causal belief dimensions: Psychosocial Stressors, Supernatural Retribution, Biomedical Defects, and Socio-Environmental Deprivation. Psychosocial Stressors and Supernatural Retribution were rated more important causes of mental than physical illnesses. Prayer and home/family care were suggested more strongly for treating mental than physical illnesses. Systematic associations were found between causal beliefs, treatment beliefs, and attitudes towards patients. Ss' educational level was negatively related with traditional beliefs and positively related with favorable attitudes towards patients. Results indicate that causal beliefs, perceived importance of treatments, and attitude towards patients among northwestern Ethiopians are meaningfully interrelated. Implications for health services and research are discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: causal & treatment beliefs & attitudes toward schizophrenia & depression & anxiety disorder & alcoholism & mental retardation & tuberculosis & leprosy & poliomyelitic paralysis;1770 yr olds;Health Knowledge;Mental Illness (Attitudes Toward);Physical Illness (Attitudes Toward);Treatment;Intellectual Development Disorder;Alcoholism;Anxiety Disorders;Infectious Disorders;Major Depression;Schizophrenia;Tuberculosis

title: Survivors of torture:  An investigation of ethnocultural identification, causal attributions, and quality of life
authors: Bohrer, Barbara Mcgreevy
abstract: Torture is practiced worldwide to further the ideologies of governments and political groups. Increasingly, survivors are fleeing their countries to seek asylum in the West. Research on torture survivors has recently become an emerging field in mental health and psychologists are increasingly likely to encounter and treat survivors of torture.  The purpose of this research was to examine the extent to which ethnocultural identification and causal attributions account for quality of life in adult survivors of torture. The researcher applied attribution theory as a conceptual foundation to better understand how survivors find meaning for the good and bad events in their lives. The research also aimed to better understand the characteristics of torture survivors and to make recommendations to improve the quality of mental health care. The research questions asked the extent to which ethnocultural identification and causal attributions accounted for quality of life in survivors of torture and to what extent the causal dimensions of locus of causality, stability and controllability accounted for quality of life when controlling for the effects of ethnocultural identification. Additional supplementary analyses were included to investigate the relations among selected demographic and major variables.  The sample was highly diverse demographically and included 45 participants in treatment at the Bellevue/NYU Program for Survivors of Torture in New York City. Results revealed that ethnocultural identification and causal attributions did not explain a significant portion of the variance in quality of life. Likewise, the causal dimensions did not account for a significant portion of the variance in quality of life. Supplementary analysis revealed the following significant findings: participants in treatment for longer periods were more likely to report a better quality of life, those with higher levels of education were more likely to report a better quality of life and a greater sense of overall control in their lives, and more educated survivors were in treatment for longer periods of time. Finally, Asian participants expressed a stronger identification and attachment with their ethnocultural group than either White or Black participants. Implications for research, theory, and treatment for psychologists working with this population an discussed. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: ethnocultural identification & causal attributions;quality of life;adult survivors of torture;Attribution;Ethnic Identity;Quality of Life;Torture;Survivors

title: Cognitive specificity of depression and anxiety: Methodological issues and research findings
journal: Psychology: The Journal of the Hellenic Psychological Society
authors: Kleftaras, George
abstract: An increasing number of studies question the distinctiveness of depression and anxiety and show, firstly, that depression and anxiety are highly correlated and, secondly, that many of the cognitive mechanisms that characterize them are very similar. Thus, although there are numerous studies concerning depression and anxiety separately, there is relative confusion regarding the cognitive variables which differentiate each of them. It is becoming increasingly clear that the study of cognitive specificity of depression and anxiety requires a comparative methodological approach that differentiates these states in the same study. In this paper the conclusions of a relatively limited number of studies adopting such an approach are presented. These studies generally focus on 'thought content', 'locus of control', 'causal attributions' and 'information processing'. Then, implications of these findings as well as certain methodological issues and weak points are discussed and, finally, ways are proposed in order to deal with them. More specifically, the discussion focuses mostly on the general distress (psychopathology) factor, the methods of assessment, the chronobiology of depression and anxiety, the control groups and the comparisons of multiple groups and their combinations. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: cognitive specificity;methodological approach;depression;information processing;cognitive mechanisms;causal attributions;anxiety;thought content;locus of control;Anxiety;Cognitions;Internal External Locus of Control;Major Depression;Methodology;Attribution;Cognitive Processes;Cognition

title: How stigmatising is schizophrenia in India?
authors: Thara, R. and Srinivasan, T. N.
abstract: Investigated the nature and degree of stigma experienced by primary caregivers of schizophrenic patients in southern India, and associations between stigma, social variables, and perceived causes of illness. Ss were 159 primary caregivers (mean age 50.3 yrs) of schizophrenia outpatients predominantly patients' parents. Caregivers rated 14 items concerning stigma, including difficulties with neighbors, marriage, shame, and guilt. Results show that a third of caregivers had no explanation for the illness and these respondents reported higher levels of stigma than those who attributed a definite factor. Stigma was higher if the patient was female, if patients and caregivers were younger in age, and if causes of the illness were attributed to character or lifestyle, substance abuse, problems in interpersonal relationships, or faulty biological functioning. Marriage, fear of rejection by a neighbor, and the need to hide the illness from others were the most stigmatizing aspects reported by caregivers. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)

title: [Therapeutic goals and indications: psychotherapy patient's self-reports during diagnostic assessment].
authors: Faller, H
abstract: Although individual therapeutic goals are considered to be important factors motivating patients to engage in therapeutic work, they have gained little attention in empirical research. In the present study, patients were given a questionnaire containing 24 therapeutic goals which could be rated according to their subjective relevance on a 5-point scale. N = 152 patients (mean age 34.5 years, 59.2% female) who presented at a university psychotherapy outpatient department to attend a diagnostic interview participated in the study. "To solve my problems" and "to get relief from my complaints" were the goals that were rated as most important. Goals pertaining to mental health such as more contentness and calmness, self-assertion and insight scored high, too. Three rational scales were constructed: 1. insight, 2. sociability, and 3. self-assertion. These scales were correlated with both patients' causal attributions and therapy expectations in plausible ways. However, the general strength of intercorrelations point of the conception patients goals were not very succinct at the time of the intake interview. Indication groups regarding specific therapeutic measures did not differ with respect to therapy goals. Only the general decision whether to recommend a psychotherapeutic intervention or not seemed to be influenced by patients' therapeutic aims.
keywords: Psychotherapy*;Mental Disorders/*diagnosis;Assertiveness;Humans;Mental Disorders/psychology;Self-Assessment;Social Behavior;Psychotherapy

title: Religious interpretations of mental distress: Empirical findings and clinical implications
authors: Pfeifer, Samuel
abstract: Religious interpretations of causality can be understood in the framework of cultural sensitivity, which is underlined in new formulations of the Diagnostic and Statistical Manual of Mental Disorders-IV (DSM-IV). In an empirical study of 343 predominantly Protestant patients, who described themselves as religious, demonic explanations were found in 37.6%. 30.3% sought help through ritual 'prayers of deliverance' (with more or less exorcistic content). Functions of demonic attributions as well as the various forms of deliverance rituals are described. Often patients do not hold rigid convictions of the spiritual causes of their illness. Rather they are developing very subjective interpretations which exist side by side with other medically oriented explanatory models. Although many patients reported beneficial effects as a result of deliverance rituals, psychiatric examination could not observe extraordinary or lasting changes in the symptomatology. Discrepancies in the causal attributions can lead to tensions between therapist and patient. Assessment of religious attributions and their functions should lead to a 'shared construction of meaning' resulting in better support and coping. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: mental distress;religious interpretations of causality;Protestants;outpatients;Attribution;Distress;Mental Disorders;Religion

title: Attitudes towards mental health in an urban Pakistani community in the United Kingdom
authors: Tabassum, Rashda and Macaskill, Ann and Ahmad, Iftikhar
abstract: Examined attitudes towards mental health issues by Pakistani family members living in an urban area of England. 22 Pakistani males (aged 3065 yrs) and 29 1st-generation and 23 2nd-generation Pakistani females (aged 1270 yrs) living with high levels of social isolation completed interviews. Topics included the etiology of psychiatric illness, mental illness and marriage, decision making within the family regarding treatment for mental illness, and reasons for not seeking help. Responses were evaluated in terms of applicability to both Western medical etic models and emic models based on patient perspectives. Results show that Ss identified language differences and religious and cultural practices as barriers to treatment. First-generation female Ss identified depression as a core symptom. Perceived causes of mental illness emphasized stress as the main factor, followed by unhappiness. Females also included strained relationships as a significant factor, but males did not. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: perceived mental health issues & barriers & causes;1270 yr old male vs 1st vs 3nd generation female Pakistanis living in England;Adult;Aged;Attitude to Health;Female;Great Britain;Humans;Male;Mental Disorders;Mental Health;Middle Aged;Pakistan;Residence Characteristics;Urban Population;Human Sex Differences;Immigration;Mental Illness (Attitudes Toward);Sociocultural Factors;Urban Health;Attitude

title: Causale attributies in de ambulante behandeling van psychiatrische patinten = Causal attributions in the treatment of psychiatric out-patients
authors: Veeninga, Arend and Kraaimaat, Floor
abstract: Studied the relationship between (1) causal attributions for symptoms and (2) treatment outcome for 87 male and female psychiatric outpatients (mean age 38.9 yrs) in the Netherlands. Most Ss had long-term adjustment disorders, affective syndromes, or anxiety syndromes, in decreasing order of frequency. Ss received cognitivebehavioral individual or group therapy. The Attribution Checklist (an adaptation of a Dutch scale) and the Dutch versions of the SCL-90 and the Somatic Interpretation Questionnaire (J. M. Robbins and L. J. Kirmayer, 1991) were administered at the beginning of treatment and 4 mo later. The results indicate that Ss used a variety of physical, psychological, and environmental explanations for their symptoms. No evidence was found that specific types of explanations were associated with treatment dropout or with treatment outcome. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)
keywords: symptom causes & treatment outcomes;psychiatric outpatients (mean age 38.9 yrs);Mental Disorders;Pathology;Symptoms;Treatment Outcomes;Causality

title: [Causal attribution and personality in psychotherapy patients].
journal: Zeitschrift fur Psychosomatische Medizin und Psychotherapie
authors: Faller, H and Walitza, S
abstract: The present study addressed the relationship between patients' causal attributions of their disorders on one hand and their personality traits on the other. The investigation was based on the self-reports of 197 psychotherapy patients who presented at a university outpatient department for diagnostic evaluation. Personality traits were measured using the Giessen-Test (Beckmann et al., 1991), causal attributions were assessed by a check list (Faller 1997). Intrapsychic causal factors were rated highest; after those, interpersonal and social factors followed next, while somatic factors were judged to be least important. Psychosocial attributions showed strong correlations with the self-report of depressed mood in the Giessen-Test. Similar relations were found with other personality traits such as low ratings of social resonance, low openness, and low social potency. The reported interrelations suggest that psychological symptoms, personality and causal atttributions are closely intertwined.

title: Persnlichkeit und subjektive Krankheitstheorien bei Psychotherapiepatienten = Causal attribution and personality in psychotherapy patients
journal: Zeitschrift fr Psychosomatische Medizin und Psychotherapie
authors: Faller, Von Hermann and Walitza, Susanne
abstract: This study addressed the relationship between patients' causal attributions of their disorders and their personality traits. The investigation was based on the self-reports of 197 psychotherapy patients who presented at a university outpatient department for diagnostic evaluation. Personality traits were measured using the GieSen-Test (D. Beckmann et al, 1991), causal attributions were assessed by a checklist (H. Faller, 1997). Intrapsychic causal factors were rated highest; after those, interpersonal and social factors followed next, while somatic factors were judged to be least important. Psychosocial attributions showed strong correlations with the self-report of depressed mood in the Gieen-Test. Similar relations were found with other personality traits such as low ratings of social resonance, low openness, and low social potency. The reported interrelations suggest that psychological symptoms, personality, and causal attributions are closely intertwined. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2017 APA, all rights reserved)

title: Dentists' perceived stress and its relation to perceptions about anxious patients.
authors: Moore, R and Brdsgaard, I
abstract: Dentists' perceptions about the stressfulness of dental practice, their perceptions about dental anxiety and its management were surveyed in a descriptive study. A mailed questionnaire was completed by 216 randomly selected Danish private dentists. Of these, nearly 60% perceived dentistry as more stressful than other professions. Dentist perceptions of the most intense stressors were (ranked): 1) running behind schedule, 2) causing pain, 3) heavy work load, 4) late patients and 5) anxious patients. Bivariate odds ratio (OR) analyses were undertaken to check for associations of perceived stress and other dentist variables with perceptual outcomes about anxious patients. Signs of dental anxiety were reported to be less often spotted by older (> or = 52 yr) dentists (OR=3.1) who perceived their job stress to be greater than that of other professionals (OR=3.2). Perceived causes of dental anxiety (1st, 2nd or 3rd choices tallied and then ranked) were 1) fear of pain, 2) trauma in dental treatment, 3) general psychological problems, 4) shame about dental status and 5) economic excuses. Dentists who reported that dental anxiety was primarily the result of general psychological problems in patients, usually had solo (OR=2.4) practices older than 18 years (OR=2.6) and reported high perceived stress (OR=2.2). Adjusted odds ratios for these two dentist perception outcomes about anxious patients generally improved strength of associations and confidence intervals. There were no meaningful differences by practice location or perceived public image. Also, there was no significant association between the use of pharmacological strategies for anxiety and the perceived stress of dentists. Nearly all dentists talked with anxious patients as their main treatment strategy. It was concluded that psychosocial aspects of dental practice have meaningful and often adverse associations with dentist perceptions about anxious patients. Some dentists appeared to require more knowledge about dental anxiety and managing their own stress.

title: Natural course of symptoms in Cambodia veterans: A follow-up study
authors: de Vries, M. and Soetekouw, P. M. M. B. and Van Der Meer, J. W. M. and Bleihenberg, G.
abstract: Evaluated the natural course of symptoms in Dutch servicemen who had been deployed in the 199293 peace operation in Cambodia in a prospective study. At 18-mo follow-up, a questionnaire was completed by 227 veterans who met a set case definition for symptoms in Cambodia veterans or who had sub-threshold scores. Initial measurement of fatigue severity, psychological well-being, depression, posttraumatic stress disorder (PTSD), trait-anxiety, self-efficacy, and causal attributions was used to evaluate predictors for self-reported improvement and low levels of fatigue at follow-up. 19% of the Ss reported complete recovery, 20% felt much better, 57% had the same complaints and 4% had become worse compared with their initial assessment. Self-reported improvement and less severe fatigue at follow-up were predicted by less severe fatigue at initial assessment and more perceived control over symptoms. Self-reported improvement was reported in a considerable percentage of Ss, whereas another substantial percentage of Ss continued to suffer with severe levels of fatigue and related symptoms. Predictors of improvement in Cambodia veterans and patients with chronic fatigue syndrome show similarities and also may bear importance for Gulf War veterans. (PsycINFO Database Record (c) 2016 APA, all rights reserved)
